Blog.post: The way I see it, there is no real karmic justice-- at least not in the way most people expect it to be. Instead of rewards for good things and punishments for bad things, I see it as sort of a way to equal out good and bad things in a person's life. You see, life is like a rubber band stretched taught between your fingers. Every time something good happens, the rubber band is pulled tighter. For instance, if you have a good day: you spend the day with your crush, you recover from an incurable disease, you become the queen of your own country-- all these merit another yank on the rubber band of your life. And then, when you start to think that maybe everything will go your way for a change... SNAP! All of the positive events break the strained rubber band and it'll come flying back to hit you in the face with as much negative force as it built up with all of the happy goings-on. It'll all come back around with counters to everything pleasant and then some-- come back and hit you right in the eye. That, my friend, is the rubber band theory.

I am a coward. A horrible, snivelling coward. I'm running away as you read this. Maybe if I were braver... I would have the strength to say... I lied. I admitt it. I lied to you. I said that nothing was wrong. But the fact is... ... something is very wrong.... ... only we can't talk about it. I'm afraid to. If I speak it aloud, the issue will then become a real, solid problem-- and problems have to be fixed. But the thing is, I can't imagine a pain-free solution. You see, if I speak it aloud... ... everything just might fall apart...

"And everything I said about how messed your head is, We're cut up and left in bits and pieces on the ground. And we learn as we age. Wait for nothing and my body still aches. And you take 'cause they give, Though I love you; and my body-- it leaks like a siv. Take the picture from the wall When you think that nothing matters. Take the picture from the frame And it's a long ways to the floor. Cut your finger on the edge 'Cause it's sharper than they told you. Take a leap from out the window 'Cause it's way too far to go through the door...." Jaws Theme Swimming , Brand New I'm so damn sick of this. I'm sick of feeling like a bug in a jar. I can't do anything to help myself and there's eyes all around me. Everyone's prodding me, taunting me, pulling off my limbs one by one and laughing while they do it. And all I can do is let it happen because I'm just a stupid, insignficant, sad little girl. I'm SICK OF IT! HOW MANY TIMES DO I HAVE TO LET YOU KICK ME BEFORE YOU REALIZE I'M NOT FIGHTING ?! I'D RATHER BE DEAD THAN SOMEONE'S FUCKING PINCUSHION!!! I hate everything about my life-- all I can think about are reasons for it ending. Everything dear to me is in so many fucking pieces right now I don't know if I'll ever be able to fix them. Every time I try the people I try so hard to be happy for smack the bits from my hands and stomp on them. I can't make progress because, for some reason, everyone's so damn dead-set against it. I look to God but He's not answering. I don't know what else to do. If there was a way to leave everything behind and never return, I'd jump at the chance and not bother to look back. There's no real reason for me to stick around anyways. I realize now that there's nothing for me here except despair, heartache, and fucked up ideals. Do you hear me? Do you get the message, all you fucking fates burning me like an ant under a magnifying glass?? I give up... it's over... just let me fucking die already...

"Vacation, need a little sun to break up All the frustration and turn it into love. Ain't nobody gonna tell us what we're gonna do Because today It's up to me an' you..." ~ Vacation by Vitamin C Finally, after months of back-breaking toil and long hours of insomniac musings, my week of rest has come! Tomorrow I head out to Florida with the rest of my highschool's band members (whee!), and from then until Sunday it'll be nothing but relaxation! Sun tan lotion, sandles, souviners, and plenty of SAND! A week away from bitching mothers and flu-ridden little brothers and angry fathers and all the pressures of school. God, this must be heaven! This deserves a celebration... though the best I can do right now is delay homework assignments and dance around in my room. Ah well, after all the stress sophmore year has put me through, I deserve a break before everything gets out of control and I snap. My life had been speeding in a downward spiral, drilling me painfully into the ground and weighing me down with 'responsibility.' Christ, adults have no idea how difficult it is to keep all the balls in the air; to them responsibility builds character. Feh, yeah right. Character my ass. All week I tried leaning towards people, indulging in the feminine instincts to find someone to sympathize with my horrible experiences, but found that no one wanted to hear my rants. So, halleluja, thank God for the internet. Blogs are a great way to filter rampant emotions. It's at times like this when I feel really lonely, lacking a shoulder to lean on. Maybe in Florida I'll feel happy enough to flirt a little. Who knows? I may actually catch someone's eye when I'm down there. That'd be nice. A person needs a comforting hug every once and a while! On a side note, why do guys act thicker than they really are? I mean, not every dude can be so simple that kicking a bottle into a moving fan would be amusing three times in a row... Then again, maybe they could. Anyways, it usually seems to me that guys with an intelligence over the expected level for men are shunned (there aren't many...) Today I told some jerk that he was shallow, and he had to ask the definition from a friend. The friend replied as if it were totally obvious, "Dude, it's, like, not deep..." Ladies and gentlemen, the Y-Chromosome. Stupid leading the stupid. Okay, okay, enough ranting. Time to enjoy my vacation as blissfully as possible! Hasn't this been a shorter, more light-hearted blog, overall? Don't expect to many of those. Adios, amigos, yo escribir cuando tengo tiempo. (Bye, friends, I'll write when I have time)

"Never take life too seriously, you'll never get out of it alive." ~ Anonymous If there's one thing I ever hated about myself, it was my uncanny ability to send myself into uncomprehensible nervous breakdowns. Since I first attended school, everything seemed so important, life-stakingly important. Everything was dictated around this, and if things didn't get done, I absolutely freaked. I'd cry, I'd loose sleep, I'd make myself utterly sick worrying. I constantly searched my mind for some kind of solution, and when I found none, I had the closest possible thing to a heartattack. I'm surprised I didn't accidentally give myself an anxiety attack after all that. I guess this loathed fault comes from my parents; they always stressed the importance of perfection and punctuality. I always had to have strait A's, I could never get in trouble, I had to practice piano for a hour every day, I had to sit up strait and obey my elders, I had to speak politely and never ever talk back. I did what I was told, and I became very obedient. Disgustingly so. I was youthfully naive, and I can't stand to think of myself as their 'prodigy daughter'. However, it was obviously not in my nature to stay so docile. Eventually, I grew tired --no-- frantic. I was unable to maintain the level of perfection they wanted from me. It was too much for me to handle anymore, but still they pushed. This time, I pushed back. I finally realized that I was weary from all of it, and sure I tried my best but if it wasn't good enough, well, they could just kiss my ass. Deal with it. I am not perfect. I am not an A student. I hate the piano. I speak my mind, whether or not it is appropriate. And I don't always want to do what I'm told. Teenage rebellion, some may call it. But I see it as finally freeing myself from what would inevitably lead to my demise. Had I remained under their hold much longer, there is no doubt in my mind that I would have snapped. I would have either gone crazy or killed myself, whichever came first, only to escape the madness. It bothers me now that I ever was that way, though I still worry greatly as if I have something to prove. My parents have realized that they can't expect a prodigy from me anymore, and have let off, putting their hopes and dreams on my little brother. I pity his wretched soul, but am grateful that it is not me they strictly diciplin anymore. The effects of their stern 'caring' still resides within me, though. I cannot go about my life as freely as I want. I want to be carefree, I want to be indifferent, aloof, like a cat. Independant, unaffected and unattatched. I am still tied down to all these problems with my life, so wrapped up in them I can't take the time to be happy. School, the future, everything means too much; it has become far to important to me to simply brush off (despite how desperately I want to). They say to life isn't hard when you realize you only have to do it once... Fuck that. You only have once. Once to do it right. Like I need that kind of pressure. I've found that we're all too busy preparing for the future that we never have any time to enjoy the present. What's the point in living when you only learn to live after you're dead and gone? Before you know it, you're life is spent, and you find yourself 90 years older, alone in a nursing home with every disease known to man PLUS a broken hip, pondering the 'what if's. The worst fate I can think of besides flat out insanity, would be to be haunted by those 'what if's. What if I never was badgered by my parents? What if I didn't care now? What if when I had the chance I stuck with it? What if I let go? What if... No one can live like this. No one should live like this.

"All day, staring at the ceiling, Making friends with the shadows on my wall. All night, I hear the voices Telling me that I should get some sleep Because tomorrow might be good For something..." ~ Unwell by Matchbox 20 One thing I've noticed about girls: we are social creatures with a basic need for a pack. We have a certian social order in our herds, a feudal system if you will, but all members of each tribe are brought together with the equally strong need for companionship. We learn our place quickly in our packs, for refusing to obey by the heiarchy could result in expulsion from the group. Deep down, no girl ever wants to be alone, and those who find themselves solitary are usually unhappy. We need the comfort of another's presense, in case something crucial happens or we suddenly devulge in a craving for triple-chocolate-mousse. Why else do girls absolutely have to go to the bathroom in pairs?! To make sure that the other doesn't do something stupid or have something awful happen to that person. There are the obvious leaders, the Alpha(s), maybe not the most outspoken females but retaining a sophisticated and intimidating air; these women guide the others in the direction most appealing. The rest are followers, which can be classified into three groups: the Brazen, the Bitches, and the Bashful. Brazen femmes are usually the voice of the herd, loud and a tad bit eccentric with a comical flair that keeps the rest of the pack attentive. Not quite secure enough to be a leader, but respected equally as much, making the Brazen second in comand. The Bitches are the groaners of the tribe, feline in their attributes with a sense of aloofness that clearly states that they are there only when interested, and never because they actually need the comradship. They laze around in the security of one tribe before galavanting off to find another when one gets too boring for their tastes. These women are usually more assertive, comanding a certian amount of respect while still finding themselves humbled by the Alpha and Brazen. Bitches are third in the social order. And last but certianly not least, the Bashful. We all know the type: shy, quiet, unargumentitive, with a timidness akin to that of a rabbit or mouse. Too tentative to say anything that might upset anyone, they follow along without much protest, simply enjoying the company in silent contentment. They are the human version of an Omega, the lowest on the list and usually the most abused by the higher-ranking members of the herd, though mostly in good fun, of course. Do men have this sort of social order? My friends tell me I pay too close attention to irrelevant details; such as how some people chew their lower lip when their nervous, or how a few people refuse to eat food that's been cross-contaminated (It all goes to the same place anyways, so what's the big deal?). They tell me I should look at the bigger picture. However, I must confess, the thought of seeing only the big picture frightens me. Quite a bit, actually. I read an Inu-Yasha fanfic today, y'know, one of those online dealies that have the characters of a movie/show/book/game in an alternate universe. This one was quite good, and I found myself hooked... up until the sequal, that is. Poor Inu-Yasha is driven insane by the pressures and responsibilities in his life, going completely beserk and killing everyone! Could this be me? I find myself sometimes hearing voices, and it frightens me. I know what you're thinking, 'Oh, stop exaggerating, moron, you're imagining things. It's nothing, you're fine.' And this may be true. But they frighten me, sometimes, when they catch me by surprise. They never talk directly to me, they always sound like someone far away, on the radio or from behind a wall. I try to block them out, but they come back, following me as I try to live as if I hear nothing. I am terrified of going insane. Absolutely mortified, horrified, a complete and utter shivering mass of useless flesh and bones. I don't want to loose my head. I don't want to be taunted by the tricks of the mind, nor do I want to loose that blurry yet existant line between fantasy and reality. Sometimes, concentrating on the little things makes me feel more comfortable, as if the whole world were not as morbid and sadistic as it really is; like they say, ignorence is bliss. I can forget about everything else in 'the big picture' if I focus diligently on something little, the smallest, most insignificant thing I can find, be it a blade of grass or a breeze on the lake. Seeing the big picture would force me to see the errors with my future, holes in my plans. I fear this more than death itself. To loose one's mind is to loose one's soul. Once insane, you become nothing but a shell of your former self, something I wouldn't wish upon anyone. If I see the world for what it really is, a mental breakdown is inevitable, and so I remain determine to think only about the little things. Take things as they come. Relax. Breathe. But the voices, they still haunt me. God, what am I supposed to do? I can't tell anyone. No one would believe it, and those who did would think me a maniac. So what choices do I have? Bottled up inside the voices will grow, I'm almost positive, until they consume me and eat away at the darkest resesses of my mind. I will become a shell. An empty shell. But revealing this dark shame would torment me just as much. No one would trust me, no one would listen, no one would be able to look me in the eye without fear in their own. No one fears me. Not before, not ever. It's impossible. How much longer, though... how much longer until I can no longer recognize myself, how much longer until butterflies dance in my vision, how much longer do I have to sleep dreamlessly, how much longer? Pray for me, I fight the demons alone. "I'm not crazy, I'm just a little unwell. I know right now you can't tell. But stay a while and maybe then you'll see A different side of me..."

"Call me, call me, Let me know you were there. Call me, call me, I wanna know you still care, Now, won't you come and Ease my mind..." ~ Call me, call me by Yoko Kanno I never figured out how rainy days could be so somber. It's almost like every raindrop is a tear for this god-damn dreary world. Maybe it's just me living in a romanticized version of the world, but doesn't it seem like it's harder to smile during days like these? They say that mysterious people love the rain. They dance in it, season their food with it, live their lives like scattered raindrops without reason or care. I wish to be like them. Shit, every time I talk it's like I'm quoting some cheesy romance novel; big words, naïveté, and self-loathing laced through each sentance. From what I write, people might start thinking I'm some kind of whiney little kid who "can't appreciate the world". Still, it's not like there will be more than a few random people skimming through my list of angsty blogs, so I really shouldn't fuss about it. Y'know, sometimes I wonder if we're meant to be the people we are. I mean, are rainy days supposed to be gloomy? Are mysterious people always attracted that gloom? If you passed me on the street, I know that there would be nothing that would strike you. You would walk by without so much as a glance, overlooking my presence because I am part of the blur. If you saw me again, you would not recognize my face. What sort of person am I? An ordinary one. Brownish-black hair, brown eyes, plain face, nothing that would strike anyone as beautiful or breath-taking. Maybe that's why I find myself drawn to the characters of fiction. So unrealistically different, yet utterly beautiful. They can be innocent and seductive at the same time. They can be cool, elegant, and radiant no matter what. They can have windy, wistful smiles that haunt the minds of others and draw suitors to them like moths to a flame. In fiction, a person can stand out in a crowd without exertion. Today I went outside. For the first time in a while, I went out on my own accord. It was brisk, and rain drizzled down lightly and condensed on my glasses, but it was a good fresh feeling. I sat out on the porch for a while-- that is, before my mother berated me for being an wierdo and demanded I come inside before catching cold. Who does that, anyway? I mean, thinking out on the porch in the rain is something you'd expect from an emotionally-faceted character from a movie or book, and makes a person look rather foolish in real life. But I thought I'd try it anyways. And it did make me feel better. This morning had been especially-- for lack of a better word-- shitty. My alarm went off inconceivably early for a Saturday, leaving me sleep-deprived and ready to bite someone's head off. The reason for this early morning was State Solo and Ensamble. After scrambling at the last minute to get everything in order yesterday, my friends and I decided to play the next morning. So here I was, awake durring the wee-hours of Saturday (which, by all laws of human nature, should NOT exist), and frantically trying to get ready while my brain was still fuzzy with sleep. By the time I finally got there, I had half the household angry with me and my own anger levels rising uncomfortably high. You'll laugh at me when I tell you the rest: it was all for nothing! Turns out that our accompanist decided not to show, leaving us there STRANDED for an hour and a half. All that bitching only to sit around and wait. The desolation of the rain strikes again. Also, I was reminded this morning that I hated grocery shopping. My mother dragged me along, to my great despondency, shopping to stock up our house for a week with edible foods. It isn't so much the store as it is the time it takes. I mean, they have at least a million things in there, over half of which you would never need or use; yet they still fill their shelves to the brim with this worthless crap so that you must rumage through it all to find the stuff you really need. The aisles are either freezing cold or swelteringly hot, and the constant buzzing of elevator music from the speakers above accompanied by the screams of small children is enough to drive a person completely insane. And on a side note, why do parents have the urge to drag their children everywhere? Well, there's my morning, lain out for you all neat-like and meticulously described. And it rained. I think it's still raining now, though it's hard to tell. The doves have come back. Every summer for the past three years, a pair of doves have taken it upon themselves to nest in our garage and perch themselves on the telephone wires outside my window. The rain doesn't seem to bother them, I don't think. Pretty little things, delicate and peaceful. Their whole world spins around each other, for I rarely see one without the other. I don't think they know or wonder about the yelling that goes on inside this house, or muse over the war between the U.S. and Iraq, or a million other things. Must be nice to live life with such simplicity. All you need is that other dove, and everything is right. Nothing to worry about, nothing to think about, just enjoy the company of your companion. No need to fret about the rain, we'll just find a nice, dry branch and wait it out. It'll go away eventually. For animals of such low intelligence, those damn birds seem to know how to live life more contentedly than I. Maybe one day I'll figure out what it is I want from this wretched world. Until then, sayonara.

"Once upon a year gone by she saw herself give in. Every time she closed her eyes she saw what could have been. Well, nothing hurts and nothing bleeds when covers tucked in tight. S' funny when the bottom drops how she forgets to fight... to fight... And it's one more day in paradise..." Paradise by *gags* Vanessa Carlton Friday night. Young people like me should be out and enjoying the freedom of a promissing weekend, not pondering the strange injustices of the world. It's not like I have nothing to do, but the procrastination of what have you gives way to incomprehensible musings that even the great void of the internet can't subside. I can't quite get it sometimes. I mean, hey, you only get to live once, why not go out and live normally for God's sake? Do things a normal teenage girl would do! Date, go to concerts, party, get drunk, go to the movies, loose your virginity, hang out at the local Big Boys with the gang, y'know. That sort of stuff. That's normal. Hell, if there's one thing I've learned after years on the recieving end of some pretty distinct 'Good-lord-what's-up-with-her' looks, it's that there is no normal. What people expect and what people do are two completely different agendas, my friend. I've come to learn that life is just one huge cliché, many of it's elements completely and uninterestingly predictable. I am a plain person. I sit at home on my computer, I do my homework on time, I eat, sleep, breath normalcy. I am a slave to routine. However, I force myself to wonder if this is how I'll be spending the rest of my life, an insignificant and undefined span of time in the enormous expanse of eternity. When I'm gone, when everyone I know is gone, will people see my name and wonder about me? Will they ever think of me as a person who once lived, not some face-less phantasom lingering from the past? I can only hope that my miserable existance doesn't go to waste. But how can I do this when I thrive on consistancy? Everything about me has stayed the same for as long as I can remember. Same hair style, same stupid pink bows on my curtians, same cheerful and noisy clothes, even when I look in the mirror I see that my face hasn't changed at all. I am afraid of what will happen if, no, when everything changes. What happens when I loose the only things keeping me pinned to the earth? It's inevitable, it'll happen. Life does that to a person, spins them around and jerks them up and down until they puke out their guts on the sidewalk. And there's no way to be ready for it. Sometimes I think I deserve a good verbal spanking for all this thinking I've been doing. I think maybe I'm waiting for someone to come up to me, whack me on the head and scream, "Just let it alone, dipshit!" Poor little Emilee, a prisoner to her own thoughts. I just wish I knew for sure that all this thinking wasn't making me crazy. I don't know, I guess it's better than being an airhead without a thought or ounce of brains to occupy the space between your ears. Weighing it in my hands, I can only find that being a tad bit psycho is merely a slight inconvinience whereas being a moron is a humongous hinderence. Damn, it's gotten late, my thoughts have run away with me again. Buenos noches, mi amigos. Sleep well.

"Okay, you babes of jazz. Let's make the parties longer. Let's make the skirts shorter. Let's all go to hell in a fast car and keep it hot!" ~ Hot Honey Rag from Chicago Hahaha! Thank God for vacations! Thank God for weak-minded fools! The whole art issue has finally blown over, though a few faculty members still look at me warily from the corner of their eyes as if I'll suddenly leap up and spontaniously combust, taking the entire student body with me... The school wanted me to serve suspension, but thanks to meticulous negotiations by my parents, I'm cursed with only a few visits to a counsler with my parents. Truthfully, that frightens me more than the aspect of suspension. I hate shrinks. I had recieved many phone calls asking how things turned out from worried friends, people I never knew actually gave a damn. It was kind of nice to know that they cared so much as to find out my fate. Today, I went to the dentist to have a filling put in. God, I hate doctors. Them and their needles and foreboding instruments, the nasty rubber flavor of their gloves and the smell of disinfectant. Maybe it's the atmosphere as well, the spotless walls and white tile floors, it's far too perfect to be comfortable. But I think its the whine of the dentist drill that I hate most. That shrill, eerie drone and the feel of it digging into a molar... I shudder at the thought. Because of the drill the dentist had numbed me, and so the whole left side of my face was numb for numerous hours, durring which I was forced to hold polite conversations with store clerks. Damn the mall, damn it all to hell. Anyways, onto better and brighter news! New York City, here I come! Yet another musical trip within the span of a month. This time, the ride is with my choir, the Oakland Singers Encore. I've always dreamed of living in an alabaster city such as New York, with their looming skyscrapers and countless residents, the hustle and bustle you can't get in a small town. I've lived here since I could remember, a plain old suburban girl growing up around the same people. Nothing ever changes in this hick-town, the same ice-cream store on the corner, the same people nextdoor, the same teachers at elementary school. Faces I've seen for years still linger. Quaint houses lined up quietly, blooming with apple blossoms and lilacs in the spring, leaking in the summer, collecting snow in the winter, and leaves in the fall. Everything is so familiar and slow, I can't wait until I see the Big Apple. The fast-pace lifestyle, the rush --I can't even imagine. It makes me feel like dancing, swinging my hips a little, kicking up my heels and spinning until I can't walk strait. I want to scream out that nothing can touch me, I've finally severed my mind from the heavy ties of wordly things, I simply do not care. And everything is wonderful, even the rain can't bring me down. It was coming down in sheets earlier, overflowing the gutters and creating miniature lakes on our porch. And so I propose a toast. Drink to every victory in history, for every smile and laugh anyone has ever given. Drink to my own happiness, my own liberated mind. Cheers.

"And you can't fight the tears that ain't coming, Or a moment of truth in your lies. When everything feels like the movies, Yeah, you bleed just to know you're alive..." ~ Iris by the Goo Goo dolls Troubled. Paranoid. Insane. These are all words I'd use to describe the pathetic quivering mass of flesh that I have become. I... I just don't know anything anymore. My life seems to have pulled from my desperate grasp; the sand continues to fall between my scrambling fingers to be lost somewhere beneath me. This world is full of broken hourglasses. It seems I've finally lost my way. My frayed nerves have me hearing voices again, muffled but there, mumbling things that only I can hear. They frighten me, they create a schism within me too wide to cross or close. What am I to do when I'm being pulled from all directions? Everything has gotten out of control, my life is not my own. I can't keep up with my classes, and that in itself is a disaster. I want my future to be full of options-- damn good ones, too-- but if I don't get my grades up again, I may never see the paths I need layed before me. But everything is so hard, every test mind-numbingly difficult. Procrastinated homework has piled up on me, stacked high on a brittle foundation and threatening to collapse upon my head, threatening to smother the life from me. Friends, enemies, it's so hard to keep track of what arguments were my fault. I'm edgy around everyone, especially those I care about-- my closest friends-- I can't keep up with their enthusiastic optimism. People wanting things from me, all these wonderous things that I can no longer give, I have nothing left. I had a feeling I'd been scraping the bottom of the barrel for quite some time now, but I never knew... I never knew this was how empty I was. For a while, I had one small escape: my art. I could draw whatever I wanted, only to escape for a while into a world where I decided the pressures and restrictions. I could vent my pent-up anger, my loneliness, my fear. I basked in the praise I got when people looked over my shoulder to see what I was doing, I loved the attention. It was a way to heal my wounds and build my self-confidence a bit. It was a wonderful release. But my flaccid fingers couldn't hold it. Durring the Disney trip, our orchestra pulled the best members of our band and (literally) forced them to attend a clinic instead of going to MGM studios. The band was enraged. Furious. Livid. We threw a fit, but hell, there was nothing we could do. We were like a breeze against a brick wall. The administration would not be moved. So, we attended the clinic, and it was downhill after that. The soloist, whom we had the "privilege" of working with, definately had a majorly spiky tree UP HIS ASS !! The man was a total dick, completely pompus and the whole situation made me sick. His solo piece, The Flight of the Bumblebee had barely any brass; hell, I only had ONE note in the entire song (Keep in mind, we're wasting valuable MGM time at this clinic and the faster we finish the sooner we get to go to MGM). The soloist had tempo problems, but refused to watch the directer, and the directer decided that he didn't care. He'd make us play it over and over again, but with only one note, I never played. It was tedious, and I hated it. We all hated it. Unfortunately, we worked on the same few measures for FIVE HOURS . The clinic should have been done in an two hours, tops. In order to vent my rage, as I normally do, I drew pictures. Pictures on the inside of my folder. Pictures that depicted a certian band directer (Stick-figure versions, of course; not up to my usual caliber but anything else would have been far to gory) getting stepped on, squished, cut in half, and set on fire. Harmless, silly doodles that no one should have ever seen. And I wasn't the only participant, a few others had their hand in 'expressing their emmotions' on my folder durring those agonizingly long five hours. After the clinic was over we rushed out, relieved, and I shut the pictures away.... I never expected anyone to find them and read the scrawled labels beneith them. So, now, I'm facing suspension from school, even expulsion for these half-assed doodles. They think I'd actually attempt to hurt a teacher? I may be on the verge of insanity, but I am not stupid. I've never been in this much trouble. I've been a good student, diligent, quiet, respectful, attentive (usually), and always clean of these sort of messes. I hadn't meant anything by the drawings, I was frustrated and upset and hell, I'm young and stupid, remember? All we of the new generation are, our minds rotted by the evils of television and video games. Everything has continued in a downward spiral, I'm feeling more alone than ever before. They even managed to take my art away from me. This wasn't the first time I had gotten in trouble for artwork of mine. Quite the contrary, actually, but there was only one other time that still rings so clear in my mind. I am ashamed to admit that when I was in kindergarten, I was crudely and cruelly violated by a male classmate. I should not be ashamed --I had done nothing to merit this horror-- but he should. The next week, we were assigned to draw a monster, a scary monster, something we were afraid of. My monster had a penis. Because it was against school rules to draw such things, I was punished. For a while after that, the other children avoided me. What had made me do something as perverted to draw that ? I refused to say. Children... even now I'm surprised at the depth of even that simple drawing which no one understood. No one at all. And yet I was punished for it. My mother called earlier today and promised me that she and my father weren't mad, I wasn't in trouble with them, but their actions belied those words. My father, usually pretty laid back, snaps at me, shouts at me, screams at me. He wanted me to take it seriously, he wanted me to understand what I already understood. I wasn't allowed to speak, because everything I said seemed to make him even angrier. So, I broke down. I cried like I was five years old. I cried like I haven't cried in so long. It's funny how fast parents forget promises, isn't it? Lectures. I hate them. Sitting around that beat-up kitchen table, biting my lips nervously and feeling my eyes well up as they berated me over so many smaller things. I had no power in these lectures, my oppinion was always wrong. I cry now as I type these words, I hate feeling so helpless to defend myself. They twist my words, they yell, and I cry some more, until everything is too hysterical to continue and they release me to the comforting confines of my room. I will recieve one tonight, no doubt, everything is awkward here. I'm walking on eggshells where ever I go, there's no where safe anymore. I'm always at a danger of doing something wrong, saying something wrong, getting myself into trouble. The voices murmer to me. I have nothing left, they have gripped me and ripped my posessions from my arms, everything I loved, everything I needed, all gone. The world has fallen around my ears, crushing me beneath its massive weight, but this time no one is there to help me. To survive, I must help myself . I am afraid. I am alone. I am broken.

"The rain of your existance is shining down on me, And the soap suds spread like a disease From the washing machine..." ~ Washing Machine by Michelle Branch I cannot find words to possibly describe to you the joy and relaxation Disney brought... nor words to describe the uttor terror and despair. Overall, the trip was a blast; I mean, who wouldn't have fun in the vacation spot of the century, surrounded by all their closest friends and NO PARENTS? It was wonderful, I was able to finally unwind and rest my mind. No problem seems quite so horrible while riding one of the fastest roller coasters in the park. Maybe that was the problem. Too much fun. A few students were stupid enough to sneak vodka into the hotels, disguising the alcohol in Gatoraid bottles. Well, the first few nights at the hotel, they and a few others (my friends included), got drunk enough to kill several horses and maybe even an ox. It was pathetic. It was disgusting. It was illegal. Of course, they got caught, but the incident completely ruined the joival mood of the whole trip. People were punished accordingly, and there is word that there will be no more trips out of state for Kettering High School. All because of some idiots who felt like getting a high at the happiest place on Earth. Bastards. Okay, okay, so I'm bitter. How depressing to come back from the warm recesses of sunny Florida to an icestorm in Michigan. We were lucky, we recieved three snow days due to lack of power. HOWEVER (there's always a downside with me, isn't there?) this means teachers frantically scrambling to catch up with their already hectic scheduals, which means twice as much homework; and with the Disney trip and all, I had plenty to make up already. I've found myself falling dangerously behind, and it frightens me. Perhaps what frightens me more is the prospect that the word 'fail' doesn't floor me the same way it used to. Sure, I'm concerned , but devastated? Nah. Procrastination and laziness are part of my character, and bad habits die hard. Like now, for instance, I could be catching up on math by figuring out all those sine, cosine, tangents, blah blah blah. But then, I wouldn't have time to write about my procrastination habits now, could I? Let's see, other happenings... Last night I went to Mott High School to see their performance of 'The Sound of Music'. And let me tell you, in all honesty, I was completely blown away. The beautiful sets, the wonderful vocal talents of the actors/actresses, the (surprisingly) amazing skills of the orchestra, it was unbelievable. I was a tad bit (maybe more than a tad bit) jealous of it all, for my own high school drama department has little to no funds, creating quite a problem when it comes to performances. We had no backdrops save for one, which we RENTED, not bought; our props were plywood and other odds and ends from home (the plywood pieces fell apart onstage durring our closing night); our orchestra was forced to play and resented it, and therefore put forth no effort; and the majority of our actors' vocal talents are close to none. Sad really. It was very exciting to head out there and see friends for the first time in years, some were acting, some were part of the orchestra, some part of the audience. Even a few of my Kettering buddies also had the intiative to show. Before the play started, I caught up with old friends from middle school (the gastly pit of Hell, middle school...) and it was in that time that I learned to be coy. I was with a friend in the orchestra, and she introduced me to the play's 'Uncle Max'. Let me just say, that boy was handsom as sin in his suits with charm and a confident, goofy aura, characteristics that always manage to attract my attention. We talked, er, flirted, but what I was surprised about was how I was able to dodge around his hooks (Amy tells me he is quite a player, and I could see why) and keep my cool. That was something I'd never been able to do before, especially when I was partially smitten. I'd always get so flustered, I'd become a stuttering, blushing idiot. But to my complete surprise, I was able to beam at his flattery with a slightly sarcastic smirk. Never done that before. I laughed and leaned away when he leaned forward, perhaps trying to back me into a perverbial corner, I answered him with witty comments, I even humored his teasing, though I couldn't help myself from stiftening under his hugs. It was a reflex, I have this paranoia of closed spaces and crowds; and man, was this guy crowding my space! Still, it made me feel... desired. I've never before felt that males saw me as anything more than a sexless maniquin. A friend at best, never a girlfriend. I don't have the curves, the pretty face, the long, shapely legs that my male-friends tell me are 'hot'. I've always been all bones and angles, skinny and bowlegged with a round Asian face. I've never been hit on, or asked out, or even known of anyone crushing on me. It just never happened, and I learned to never speak of romance in front of the guys. Despite his rather foggy intentions, I felt rather flattered that he would even look at me and think "Cute girl. Wonder if she's free later." How embarrassing. No, embarrassing borderlining pathetic; I filled up half of a blog with some story about a guy I met once. Damn, I'm a looser. A freakin' estrogen-high looser. Oh well. G'night, all you other hopeless romantics. Maybe someday we'll put our faith in love again, ne?

"I write mostly on hotel paper, Knowing that my thoughts will never leave this room. I'd be out of line telling you leave her, So I'll lie only surrounded by you..." Hotel Paper by Michelle Branch Damn, another huge gap between entries. Sorry again! Geeze, a lot has happened in the past few weeks, I don't even know where to begin-- Well, for starters, I started drawing people. Not 'real' people, mind you, cartoon/manga-type people. Maybe later I'll get off my lazy ass and scan a picture for everyone to see... I used stick to anthros and furries and weres, but I thought I'd try something new. An idea for an online manga has been floating around in my head for quite some time now, and I'm trying to perfect my drawing style so I can get some of those ideas down on paper. I've already started creating characters, two are solid and I'm debating a third. This is sort of a mental goal for me, to create some sort of storyline that I can dedicate myself to and not loose interest after a few weeks (should be quite a task). I've had thousands of comics and stories, but absolutely NONE have ever reached completion. Someday I'll pick up a few old ones again, but only after I've finished this project. I'd like it to be an ongoing story, but there are too many holes in the plot at this point, so I'm not even going to bother explaining my ideas now. Since we're on the topic of art, I'd like to mention that I had been nominated to join NAHS, the National Art Honors Society. I'm honored-- all the best artists in our school have joined, and art colleges look closely at these sort of things. It is this program that might just earn me a scholarship. However (There's always a conflict, isn't there?) I still need to take another year of a language and yet another semester of Fucked-Up-Class-From-Hell-- otherwise known as Physical Ed-- to graduate. I hate that class, myself being extremely uncoordinated and unfit. Anyways, with these classes tying down my schedual, I can't take the required art class needed for acceptance into NAHS. It completely grates my frail nerves whenever I think of how forcing us to run laps is more important than learning the subtilties and culture of different art techniques. Unbelievable, idiotic, jack-ass muscle-brained jocks. I smite thee with all the angst and anguished hate in my soul ... Lately, I've been seeing Mr. Dawson (my new councler) every other Thursday, and he's been helping me a lot. He's an okay guy, once you get past the initial 'Talk-About-Yourself-So-You-Feel-Comfortable-Spilling-Your-Guts-To-Someone-You-Know-Nothing-About' stage. We can hold real conversations now, and he doesn't patronize. We talk about anything from my own adoption to my hate for politics (President Bush especially); it's nice to be able to talk instead of listen. I have lots of friends, whom I could tell anything and not worry about having my secrets loose in the school, but I never say anything to them that I wouldn't mind publicized. I don't know, but sometimes I feel paranoid around people, untrusting and wary. Even my friends-- they simply wouldn't understand. I cadn't tell them the things that I fear, the things that I love, the things that are important to me, because they don't get it. They smile and nod and say 'oh, sure, of course', but it never sinks in. More and more I start to think that there's something wrong with me... Tonight was our band's Pops Concert. It was a blast, the best combination of jazz, dancing, friends, and bittersweet goodbyes. You see, tonight was our beloved seniors' last concert, and they went out with one hell of a bang! I'm going to miss them, because I had become close to a lot of them over the course of the year. Strange, I had never had any older friends before this, and now it seems that all my friends are upperclassmen. It's nice, but I'm positive that I'm going to be very lonely once senior year rolls around. Bleh. I hate myself when I'm happy. Have you ever heard anyone committ such a huge contraditiction to human nature in your life? But I can't deny it, I hate the person I turn into when I cut loose. I become a ditz-- a flirty, slow-witted moron who can't keep her mouth shut. I say things I don't mean before I think about it, I do things that I really shouldn't. I become loud and irritating and flippant, the kind of person I usually take pains to avoid (Cruel irony, that's what it is). Tonight was no exception, I pouted when my male friends refused to come out onto the dance floor and begged people I barely knew to dance with me. And for the record, I can't dance worth shit. I am probably the most uncoordinated, two-left-footed person on the face of the Earth. But does that stop me from trying? Hell no! Because Make-an-ass-out-of-herself-Emilee can dance if she damn well feels like it! Arg, I annoy even myself. Which brings me to my next point: I have discovered that for as many people who like me-- you know, the kinds of friends that would give a good cry at your funeral-- there are twice as many who don't. It's the kind of person I am that keeps me from being loved by all, the irreversable fact that I am 'strange' and proud of it. It hurts to think that people are merely amused by me, they tolerate my goofy-ness. After a while, that same silliness becomes irritating, and suddenly they realize again why they don't like me-- I'm annoying. And it makes me wonder, is that why I feel so alone sometimes while surrounded by so many people? Is it because those people are only putting up with me until they can't take it anymore? I hate being alone, it makes me long for someone to just hold my hand for a while, bring be back to Earth and pin me there until I can keep myself grounded. It seems that everyone has someone to do that for them, but I missing my own. I can forever watch those closest to me but only with a sad smile, feeling lonely and wishing my hands were held, too. But everyone's got someone, right? That means that I have someone, I just might not know who at this point. I can only pray they come soon, because I'm floating-- no-- drifting in the stratusphere, a long ways from the ground.

"Ring around the rosie, Pocket full of posie, Ashes, Ashes, We all fall down ..." ~ Unknown Author Wow. Extremely long pause between updates. Sorry about that, but... I fell in love. Not with a guy, like one would expect, not a living person, but a city-- the city that never sleeps. New York. "Hey, castle builder, want the moon and nothing less? Work for years then overnight success..." ~ Only In New York from 'Fairly Modern Millie' (THE BEST MUSICAL EVAH!!!) I swear to God, Gavin Creel is probably one of the best male vocalists I have ever had the pleasure to listen to. Forgive me, but there is nothing on the planet sexier than a man who can sing... The city was everything I imagined and more. The people were facinating; I felt like an alien, it was a whole new galaxy. They were rude, oblivious, hasty, loud... I spent hours just watching them. They all seemed to blend together despite the flashy clothing and odd hair styles, the city was one living, breathing thing. So many people, all going their own separate way with a mission in mind, millions of water droplets in the ocean. I could spend the rest of my life there, walking the same streets every day until I die, and I don't think I would even make a dent on those alabaster walls, I don't think I'd be recognized by even a quarter of the people I'd see every day. It was such a rush, such a thrill to grasp, the beauty and awe that anything could be so large and so alive . I was almost depressed the day we headed home. Ah, yes, back to the small town of NoWhere'sville. Where all the faces greet you the same way, where the people look at you and see you. Maybe it was a temporary dissapointment, but I missed being invisible. I feel rather empty now days. I try writing, but my words are hollow, no real meaning. I try drawing, but they remain black and white. I've hit a mental wall, and it's aggravating me to no ends. Damn, what I wouldn't give to be able to pick up my coloured pencils and give decent life to my art, what I wouldn't give to be able strum my guitar and find an appealing melody again. I saw a counsler. My mom suggested it weeks ago, hoping that we'd be able to mend our broken relationship. Honestly, I think she just wanted another adult to try and talk some sense into me. So, I decided to humor her. I went. The room smelled like some kind of stale mint, and there was a couch for me to sit and a large Lazyboy chair for Mr. Dawson. There were shelves of children's books, and framed photographs on the wall. I felt afraid, nervous, that the man would analize me and tell me I was crazy or that I was a horrible person. So, I started babbling. I rambled for about an hour and a half, stopping every fifteen minutes to wait for him to say something. When he didn't, a few minutes of silence would hang thick between us, and I would think: Fuck, we're paying for every minute I'm in here... and just like that I'd start up again on some random topic, branching further and further out from whatever I had origionally started talking about. I did go into detail about some of my relationships with my friends, a little about those with my family, I told this complete stranger how insecure I was about growing up, and about how I felt trapped and abandoned all at the same time. Initially, I felt a great release when it was over. I had always been a listener. Always a listener. I'd draw pictures while people spilled to me their woes, and I'd nod absently and add the occasional "Hmm" or "I see" or especially "I know what you mean." I'd make up stories similar to theirs, hoping to add a bit of comfort or reassurance to whatever was bothering them. I am a liar. A terrible, terrible liar. But I am so good at it. I can lie nearly flawlessly when I need to, but it has become a habbit. No harmful lies, mind you, just little white lies to get me out of harm's way, or into the limelight. They make me feel guilty, each one ringing in my mind at odd hours, echoing painfully. I hate lying, because every lie, no matter how small, grows. Always. I fear those lies, because they might drive people away. I want people to love me, to like me, to know me. When someone says they hate me, that I'm a stuck-up bitch with no concience... I lie some more, saying that I don't give a shit and walking around with a 'devil-may-care' attitude... but that's all it is, another lie. I hate for people to hate me. I don't want to be alone. I want to surround myself with people, loud people, quiet people, good people, bad people, people who I can reach out and touch with my own hands. People that know me. Maybe this means I'm self-centered, an attention grabber. Maybe I crave it. Maybe it's a high like alcohol or pot. Or maybe I just fear being alone. But I figure I already am alone, no one knows me, not really. I've woven too many lies into my life that I can't tell what's true anymore. I've toyed with reality and blurred it with my skillful tongue and gullible ears. They think things about me that aren't true. Aren't me. What about God? What does he think of my lying? I'm not pessamistic enough to think that there is no supreme being, but I do believe that he doesn't do shit in our normal lives. He's a spectator, merely waiting until we keel over and he can take us to Heaven or Hell or whatever. Hmph. Karma-coma. I like that. Some author had once feared that one day she would wake up and not be able to move because of all the horrible things she had done in her life, frozen in what she liked to refer to as a Karma-coma. I think maybe I am facing the same fate. I'll wake up one moring and find myself in some sort of paralysis, maybe not waking up at all. Dispite what people tell me, I am not a good person. There comes a time when we all have to fall. I have seen it. A person's path is always full of holes; eventually he stumbles. Well, I wanted to send these incoherent thoughts out into the void, where perhaps someone might wander in and read them, maybe learning from my follies. It comforts me that maybe my errors might not be for nothing, and so I sign off for now, wishing you the best of luck for whatever trial you are facing. Goodnight, dear void.

"'Cause it's a bittersweet symphony-- that's life, Try to make ends meat, you're a slave to money, then you die..." ~ Bittersweet Symphony , Oasis Only one word can possibly describe the frantic chaos that has become my life over the past two weeks: Finals. Yep, that's right. The six end-of-the-year tests that dictate the future of our education. These enormous exams decide what colleges we go to, what jobs we get, the lifestyle we'll have twenty years from now-- basically whether we're successful or not. Great. Of course, it doesn't help that my two hardest subjects hang dangerously in the balance of these grades; I'm right on the B-/C+ range in both Math and Science. Failing the finals would bring utter disaster and would initially-- for lack of a better word-- screw my chances of getting into an esteemed college in New York or Japan. For a while now, my greatest fear would be getting fucked up in High School and then having to deal with a crappy life afterwards. I have this immense fear of failing, of falling and never reaching my full potential... what a horrible feeling to wake up everyday and wish with every fiber in your being that you could have just one more chance to prove yourself... The very thought makes me feel ill... HOWEVER, as I have mentioned before, I am the world's biggest procrastinator. So have I studied for the Science and Math? Hell no. Probably should, but haven't. I mean, I DO have four other finals to worry about, but it seems to me that teachers are never that considerate. I mean, what kind of person would I be if I didn't devote my entire life to books and schooling, completely forsaking a normal social life or any free moments of relaxation to study text that I didn't understand in the first place? God, what do people want from me?! I mean, tell me honestly any of you who can, what does someone planning on going into music and the arts do with 4 years of advanced math/calculus, and 2 years of AP bio? NOTHING! When I'm 30 years old, do you really think I'm going to need to know how to determine the amount of Kilocaleries a common ground squirrel needs to survive each year and how many of those ground squirrels can live in any given area of the forest? Will I really need to know how to work binary and polar functions, how to find the curve of a circle intersected by two lines, blah blahblah BLAH?! Exactly. I rest my case. The end is so close, I can almost touch it; it's right there in front of me, hindered only by those damn exams. But you know what they say, "Whatever happens, happens." And as much as my frantic-paranoid-valedictorian side objects to that theory, I try my hardest to obide by it. I mean, lay back, relax. The world isn't trying to eat you alive. So, if I fail, so what? I am determined to go to college and live the life I enjoy, and a few failed finals won't prevent me from doing just that. I bet in thirty years I wont even remember if I took my finals or not. Besides, life's already in motion. Might as well go along for the ride. Don't let trivial things ruin your inner peace. Because whatever happens, happens. ~Emilee

"Now I will tell you what I've done for you, Fifty thousand years I've cried. Screaming, deceiving, and bleeding for you, And you still dont' hear me..." ~ Going Under , Evanescence Words cannot describe the frustration and anger that have filled me in the past couple days. Tears are pathetic and don't solve anything, but recently I've been sobbing in what only can be described as 'I'm-So-Frustrated-That-No-One's-Listening-To-Me-But-I-Can't-Do-Anything-About-It' kinda way. Normally I wish for harm upon myself. But now I can't help but wish for harm upon my family. I don't remember feeling so bitter about anything-- probably because nothing felt as important as what they destroyed. My parents (I have a few choice four-letter words to describe them, but will refrain from doing so)-- it's not like that don't understand, it's more like they WON'T understand. They don't want to listen and only hear/see whatever the fuck they want to see and ignore whatever facts are right in front of them. Last night was officially movie night, and so we all sat around the big screen and watched DVDs until the wee hours of the morning. I had my art supplies and such all spread out around me, my favorite lemon ice tea perched on the table with them. My idiot brother, who will remained unnamed even though his lifetime is sure to end soon if I have anything to do with it, accidentally knocks over said glass of tea and spills it all over my stuff. He tells me not to worry and that he'd clean it up, and like the fucking ignoramus I am, I believed him. I TRUSTED him to clean up the shit, and when I wake up the next morning I find all of my art supplies are coated with a film of dried, sticky, god damn fucking wads of CRAP!! ALL OF IT, RUINED!! My prisma colored pencils (expensive, god damnit!!), because of the special wax in the lead, melted and are completely unsalvagable. And, of course, when I confront the little bastard about my ruined art supplies, he shrugs and says "Oh well." I tried talking to my parents about it, but they tell me to get over it and that it wasn't a big deal. WASN'T A BIG DEAL? I'll fucking tell you what the hell is a big deal! Art is one of the most important things in my life, and having my things destroyed like that without so much as a GOD DAMN APOLOGY makes me feel like I've been beaten and robbed. My parents continue to make up exscuses to defend my brother (who does not deserve defending): he didn't see it, he didn't know . How could he fucking not know? He was the one who knocked over the god damn glass, not me! He should have known and at least TOLD ME! Then we may have been able to simply wipe off the juice, instead of now, where we fucking have to chip it off! Then, oh, then... my parents try to blame the entire fiasco on ME! My mother said, and I quote "Well, the glass shouldn't have been there." Well, mother dearest , do tell me where the fuck it should have been! On the damn couch? On the floor? NO! It was on the table WHERE GLASSES SHOULD GO!! Oh, here's another good one, "You should have done something when it happened." Uh, HELLO! It's not MY responsibility to clean up my brother's spills. He said he'd clean it up, and he DIDN'T! So now it's suddenly MY fault? God damn, they have a lot of gall trying to blame this one on me. But what REALLY irks me is that I can't get mad. I'm not allowed to yell, or to complain, or to break things; DAMNIT, I CAN'T EVEN SLAM A DOOR WITHOUT GETTING FUCKING YELLED AT! I can't tell what's holding me back... I can imagine myself running through the house and smashing things, anything, I can imagine going outside and tearing down trees. But I can't for the life of me tell what's stopping me. It gets me so frustrated that I can't do anything to show I'm angry. I can't even DRAW anymore because my art supplies are ruined and it's supposively MY GOD DAMN FAULT! They've finally done it, they've taken away my art. They don't even know how important it is to me. But they don't care.

"Don't say I'm out of touch With this rampant chaos-- Your reality. I know well what lies beyond my sleeping refuge, The nightmare I built my own world to escape..." Imaginary by Evanescence I feel like such a heel. Here I am, caught up in the violent throws of soap-opera romances in my own life when so many other things are falling precariously out of balance. My grandmother is dying. She's been horribly sick for a while, but I-- stupid, vapid me-- pushed that thought to the back of my mind to make room for chemistry and homecoming. I was happily sheltered for the first week of school, and quickly swept away with the highschool drama surrounding me. It sickens me how easily important things like my family's well-being can be forgotten in place of that cute guy in Language Arts... I feel like such a horrible person. And what's worse-- I don't feel torn up about the looming death. I don't really feel anything concerning it; it's like I'm numb inside and out. My grandpa's death had me mute for over a week, but now, all I want is for life to continue as normal... no stopping for funerals, no stopping for emotional torment, no stopping for anything. In fact, I do believe the first thought that crossed my mind after hearing "Grandma probably won't live through the weekend" was: Damn, I'm going to have to miss school for a funeral. But that's so unblelievably selfish of me, and I'm completely disgusted with myself. Death screws with everything. It's not a inconvenience, it's THE inconvenience. You loose someone you care about, you have to stop what you're doing to make time to grieve and mourn... and though I know it'd be hell to live forever, it's just as hard to adjust after death. And after I've worked so hard keeping this year molded perfectly to my expectations, something like death comes along and smashes it to bits. Despite how unorganized and slap-dash I may appear to the rest of the world, I-- like most-- am a creature of habit. I live for routine. I get up every morning at the same time, go to school, come home, get online, do homework, then go to bed. It's a system I've painstakingly set my internal clock to, and I've tried my entire life to get the tiniest elements of that schedual carefully ballanced. And now that it finally is, God once again becomes a sadistic bastard and fucks it all up. I don't know what to say or who to consult about this... I only have you, my readers, and I'm not sure if even that will help me. I'm not looking for pity, I don't want any "Oh, I'm sorry to hear that"s or "It's not your fault"s or "She was old"s. Because they won't make me feel any better. What I need right now is a hug telling me that I can change from being an awful granddaughter into a caring one before it's too late.

"I used to get away with so much, Now I can't get away. I even thought that it was simple To say the things I wanted to say..." ~ Find Your Way Back to Me by my girl, Michelle Branch Well, sorry for the long pause between updates. Blogger went psyco-crazy on me and wouldn't let me update; it kept giving me some crack-pot error for days and days and days... Anyhoo, lots to catch up on. First and foremost, BAND CAMP! *ignores the multitude of horrible band jokes that come flooding in* Yes, I, myself, am a marching band junkie, and damn proud. I love the people and hate the marching and love the gigs but hate the music. It's a priceless relationship, I can assure you. It's so weird growing up, you know? It's like everything you were isn't who you are, and everything you are is so muddled you don't know what it all is until you aren't it anymore... good god, I'm confusing myself. Let me try to simplify that run-on sentance: as you grow you change, but you don't know you've become something new until you've changed again. It's hard to explain, but it's all I got right now. I'm a junior. In high school. God, I'd never have thought I'd make it this far if you'd have asked me five years ago. It seemed like lightyears into the future from that point, and now that I'm here, it's already passing me by. First, being an upperclassmen/leader sucks. A lot. Not that the freshmen are horrible, but the responsibility and pressure is so enormous it's capable of moving bones. You've got you're MEAP and your SAT/ACTs, you've got scholarships and collage apps., so much shit is going on at once and it all dictates who'll you be. Frankly, it scares the bejesus out of me, but the way I figure it, it'll be over before I can worry about it. And where I'll go from that point on will be a mystery no matter what path I walk. Band camp really made me think about growing up. Strange, usually it only makes me think about... you know... band. This year, I realized, I only had one more chance after this to make band great. One more year until I'm gone for good. I mean, the majority of my good buddies are seniors this year, and that's it for them. They can't come back, it'll never happen again and they'll spread across the globe and I'll probably never see half of them again (sad as that is). It's like life is finally happening, and I'm finally able to see myself as an adult. I'm only half-way there, after all. Senior night almost made me cry, and it wasn't even MY senior night. It hurt so bad seeing my friends have their last camp week, and knowing that they won't come back to see mine. It was a hard realization that slapped me in the face that morning. It was almost as if the world paused to say: Wake up, idiot, next year it's your turn. It was difficult to watch, but eventually as the rest of the crowd died away and all that was left were the tight group of friends between under-classmen and seniors, I was able to give hugs and sniffle a bit under my breath. I recieved some of the tightest and most meaningful hugs in the world. It made me want to cry more. To my seniors Meghan, Courtney, Cody, Emily, Val, Brad, Renee, Mark: I LOVE YOU SO MUCH. I made lots of new friends; the freshmen are so cool this year. I was even assigned a freshman to mentor-- her name is Maegan and she's a real sweetheart. However, I'm positive I'm not the best role model, but she'll live, right? I've also developed sort of a weird magnatizm for stalkers. It's scary. They flock to me like nails. For instance, I've known for a while one of my best friend's younger siblings (a freshman this year) had sort of a crush on me (hard to believe, isn't it?). And, being the nice person I am, damnit, I decided to humor him and asked him to dance at one of the extra-activities at camp. I also decided to say yes to anyone that asked (bad move). So, now, I've got a few very annoying underclassmen following me around as if I'd suddenly toss them a bone or something. It's pathetic and I pray to god I was never that irritating as a freshman. If that weren't enough, there was a family having a reunion at the same camp the same week we were there. We met these people last year at camp (damn, some of the guys were cute.), and exchanged names and such, but that was it. No e-mail adresses, no screen names or phone numbers. HOWEVER, they rememberd my name, when I couldn't remember theirs. Or meeting them. It was rather unsettling. Also, I've discovered I get lonely sometimes, still. I don't have crushes, I'm not in love, but everyone else seems to be, and it makes me sad. There are moments when I completely adored certian people (names omitted for fear of death by embarrassment) and think: I could see myself loving you. However, these feelings always fade and I feel empty again. I hate it. Men suck. Anyhoo, there's this other thing; I've found that other people think I'm funny. Not always intentionally, but funny none-the-less. They laugh when I'm witty. They laugh when I fall. It's a great feeling, and I like it a lot. In my free time I wrote a list of things I learned at camp. Many of them are inside jokes and the many of you won't understand a wim of these, and they go something like this: WHAT I LEARNED AT BAND CAMP: -Triangles/circles suck. -Cameras are the devil. -Lifting stuff can be a wonderful waste of time. -Girls can have just as many hygene problems as guys. -Appreciate sitting. Seriously. -"Couples" aren't dating. -Rain (like triangles and circles) also sucks. -You only really need a half an hour of sleep to keep you going. -Toads are surprisingly easy to squish. -Wet shoes/socks WON'T dry if oyou "just leave them on". -Flinging food will always be fun. -After marching for over 3 hours, any instrument gains five pounds. -You are never too old for naps. -Fooseball IS a real sport. -The essential food groups can be purchased for under a dollar. -Don't get Mr. Huntoon mad (You won't like being cold). -Farmer's tans are damn sexy. -Marching fields are fragile. -The line will never be straight enough. -Showers, no matter how disgusting, are GOD. -When you fall, it's funny. -Even if you've seen the same people for the past week, there will always be something new to gossip about. -Australians are cool. -The elevator is always a better option than the stairs. -Your friends won't notice when you steal their stuff until after you turn it into the "Lost and Found". -Highschoolers singing nursery rhymes (especially tone-deaf ones), are always hillarious. -The ceiling/top bunk will always be low enough to bash your head on in the morning. -The gock block is a menace to mankind. -(For the trumpets[or more specifically, Cody]) Holds are harder than you think. -You can fit 4 drills in one of your back pockets. - EVERYBODY RUNS -Technically, tables are NOT musical instruments. -Standing in front of the snares is like being pelted in the back of the head with tiny rocks. -You'll never remember what color your shoes used to be. -Bugspray is a fine substitute fore perfume (keep poison control on speed dial). Well, Emily D. got this great idea to sign me up for skit night without my knowlege, and to have me read this list to the entire camp. Of course, skit night rolled around and they called my name and I blanched. They dragged me up kicking and screaming, and it didn't end there. I was nervous enough to piss my pants-- there were way too many eyes. But they laughed. And they laughed hard. People even asked for copies of the list. It makes me feel awsome. I know a few were only doing it to build me up a little after seeing how completely freaked out I was, but it still felt good. I finally like who I've become. Sometimes I talk to much, sometimes my jokes aren't really funny, and sometimes I do stuff I'm ashamed of, but that's okay. Because I am. And people like me. ^_____________^ Thanks guys, all my friends and readers. You guys have made my existance a tad bit more meaningful.

"SMILE, DAMNIT!" ~ Tiffany (I luv you!) It figures-- the one point in my life where I've finally found a natural high... and everyone around me is depressed. It's an epidemic, I swear. I almost feel like I've passed the bad mood onto everyone else; smile, please? Life looks so much better if you just find something insignificantly stupid to laugh at for just a moment. Trust me. ^___^ I guess this is what you call an oddity, isn't it? Emilee? Not depressed and full of teen-angst? Wonders never cease. But, for once in my pathetic existance, I feel fine. I'm hovering on a half-full, bright-sided, silver-lined cloud, and I'm determined to enjoy it, no matter how brief the ride. I've found something that makes me want to get up in the morning, a thought that rushes me through school, and ultimately gets me through the day with a smile. I'm so thankful for finding it and being able to hold it close to me when I'm feeling gloomy or nostalgic. It's something I never want to lose, but I'd share it with the world if I could. It helps not to fret too much about the bigger worries in my life-- tests, home troubles, etc.-- and to appreciate the smaller things, like the hugs I get and what I feel when I make people laugh. It makes things so much easier, and makes the world seem surreal and unimportant. I can breathe again. Still, even in my euphoria I feel slightly deflated, mostly because other people that I care about feel so cruddy. I know just how awful and empty depression makes a person feel, and I only wish I could make it better-- but I can't. No act of another could ever rectify the hole a person feels. They have to find something worth smiling about. Recently, I've been getting much closer to one of my best friends, Meghan L. We've reached some common ground, and she's been my main outlet for more personal matters that I'm unable to discuss on a public site (i.e. BOYZ!). Meghan, you rock, man. Thanks for listening to my pathetic and girlish ramblings. Not to be maudlin or anything, but I want to wish large quantities of laughter to bless the lives of those I love, and for all of my melancholy buddies to cheer up, if only slightly. I love you all, and I want you to be happy. Okay, that was a crappy conclusion to this post, but I really have nothing more to say. ^____^

"And when we're done soul searchin', When we carry the weight and died for a cause, Is misery made beautiful Right before our eyes? Mercy be revealed, Or blind us where we stand? Will we burn in heaven, Like we do down here?..." Witness , Sarah McLaghlan This post goes out to my best buddy in the entire friggin' world, Arynn, and all of you who gave me that extra hug the other day. I really needed the support, and you guys kept me my smile from faltering. I love you all so much. The few days past, my life has slowed to an eerie crawl-- I physically went through my motions and routines ever so mechanically, but in my mind I sat somewhere isolated, somewhere too far away to touch with anything other than pure will and desperation. Lethargy and depression are two dangerous substances, my friends, and I was riding on the delicious fumes of a deadly hybrid of the two. My world had suddenly become very, very simple: I existed. Purposelessly, I sat and stared with a glazed expression pondering the reasons of my being, finding only more complex questions to escalate my migraine to a new level. For a miniscule moment in time, I simply wanted to stop existing. Stop being Asian, stop being an artist, stop being a teenager, stop being horrible at math, stop being a music lover-- I wanted to stop being . Just for a second of my life, I wanted to lay down and close my eyes and never open them again... Because everything hurt. Loosing my grandmother was such a horrible experience-- she was such a beautiful person, classy and religious... In nearly one hundred years of existence she had touched so many lives, I can only hope to be part of a meager portion that was her good. Grandma Helen, I miss you. Home was a wreck, too. Being my father's remaining parent, my grandmother left him orphaned. I've never seen him so upset about anything before, and quite frankly, it scared the shit out of me. He'd get destructive in his depression-- chain-smoking like a chimney, not eating, fluctuating between extreme bursts of anger to stony isolation. It hurt us to see him hurting, and I couldn't do anything to ease that emptiness he felt. I think it was the only time I've ever seen him make my mother cry. Before any of you jump to false conclusions, he has NOT and would NEVER hit anyone. He is a gentle man, and not at all abusive in any way. It was his private grieving that worried us to the point of bitter tears. The funeral was more than I had imagined, but I think it was just as she would have wanted. It was very proper and followed religious procedures exactly as they were written (despite the boringness of it all), and was all in all very beautiful. I was even allowed to say a word for her before the final parting. I was able to mumble around my tears how grateful I was to know such a woman, how grateful for such a family, to explain how much I loved every one of them. It was emotionally taxing, but I don't regret any word of it. Arynn, you showed up and surprised me. But I cannot express how deeply touched I am by that, not with all the words in the world. You truly are an amazing person, Arynn. Your compassion and support were my pillar through the tears and the yelling at home, and I could never repay you for the security you've given me. To my friends, you showed me you cared, that you were concerned. I've never had that sort of companionship before-- my childhood was pathetically lonely for reasons I can very well understand, so it is no surprise how shocked I was at the number of people asking me if I was or would be okay. I felt important, I felt like I was needed, and THAT was my purpose. I have a purpose. I can justify my existence, because my presence is wanted by at least one soul in this world. That thought alone warmed me until I thought I'd burst with laughter and tears in unbridled happiness. It is enough for me to feel something good again, something not hollow or false, something I could wrap myself in and fill my essence with its goodness. I've felt joy, contentment, I've felt my first extremely maudlin-high-school-girl crush (there's hope for me yet !)... It's overwhelming, but I can't get enough. I haven't felt this wonderful in eons. Who cares if the questions aren't answered? I can answer them without words. Ask me. Because I'll only tell you to smile.

"I'm high but I'm grounded, I'm sane but I'm overwhelmed, I'm wrong and I'm sorry, baby..." One Hand In My Pocket by Alanis Morrisette Today, I found out there's a word that describes people like me-- it's contradictory. I want everything and nothing, I am everything and nothing. I am a walking conflict. I don't even know what I am anymore. It's like there are two halves of me, each screaming for opposite things and craving them like oxygen. I need all of these things I can't have, and I don't want any of them at the same time. I've been tearing myself in a million different directions, and haven't even known I've been doing it. Ah, now I'm beginning to confuse myself. What I wouldn't give for a nice trip to a secluded, serene area for a soul-searching journey... My thoughts and feelings are so jumbled up inside of me I can't tell what parts are me and what parts are something else. I want to know again just who exactly I am... From what little data I have collected thus far, I am eccentric (no surprise.). I'm also bubbly and outgoing, but often annoying and too peppy. I can be cynical, sarcastic and violent with a cruel sense of humor, and I also seem to have a tendency to curse like a sailor quite frequently. So, in short, I'm cheerful and jaded. A happy pessimist. Right... I want to be comforted and supported but I also want to be independent and isolated. I want to live in New York but I want to live in Montana. I never want a family but I don't want to die alone. I want to study art and music and literature and science. I want to be loved but I don't want to love, I want blue skies but I want rain, I want scars but I want to be flawless.
