I never pegged myself as the masochistic type, but I'm already tearing my spirit to scraps over this. There's just too much I'm scrabbling for with such vigor... what can I do when I can't reach?

Can you hear The voice of the children? Softly pleading For silence in their shattered world? Angry guns Preach a gospel full of hate, Blood of the innocent On their hands . Prayer of the Children 9-11-01. I can't really describe what I feel because of that day-- what I feel for America, what I feel for the world. As I have hinted in some of my other posts, I am not a very patriotic person. In fact, September 11 only strengthened my disgust for red-blooded Americans. Today, because of the anniversary of 9-11, I'd like to reflect on why I lost my faith in people who call themselves Americans. Please, these are my opinions and thoughts; if you disagree, do so to yourself. I don't need any more flames telling me what a horrible person I am for not being so arrogant about what I have. The youth, being naive to the inner workings and corruption of society, often becomes disgustingly haughty when they feel they've been wronged. Now, I will not argue that what the terrorists did was a horrible thing, and that no matter of words could justify the innocent lives they took two years ago today. HOWEVER, this is not what lowered my opinion of Americans (I am one, though I do not place myself in this category). When school came back into session after the attack, rumors were flying like bullets around the halls-- Osama, another crash, families dead, footage of people jumping out of the building... The teachers couldn't stop the overflow of morbid curiosity that we high schoolers had for this tragedy. And so, they let us talk. They called these discussions Socratic Seminars. Now, I like to see myself as a very friendly person. I pride myself in the fact that I can get along with/tolerate just about any bastard thrown my way. HOWEVER, I soon learned that I don't have any tolerance for blatant stupidity. Our class received an article by some patriotic sadist that we were required to read for this seminar, using the three-paragraph blurb as our "Text Reference". Throughout the article, the author continued to use the word " evil " to describe the terrorists and their actions. And, to put it simply, that really pissed me off. I voiced my opinion to my peers: Who are we to judge evil to good? Can anyone, for that matter, pinpoint the right from the wrong? Evil has so many facets to it, can we really just assign that title to someone WE believe is wrong? Just because we may be more privileged and run a more efficient country does not give us rights to decide just and unjust. I made sure to point out that I didn't mean to justify what the terrorists did, I only meant to amend the horrid arrogance and ignorance of anyone who thought that they knew what was evil. Had they talked to Satan? Had he TOLD them what was evil? Chances are slim to none, so he had no grounds to call anyone evil. I continued, saying that these terrorists must have had reason for sacrificing their own lives to take a jab at Mighty America, and who's to say that these reasons weren't at least somewhat understandable? It's not like people up and decide one day that they'd like to kill a million innocent people. Perhaps they, like me, were a bit miffed about the mass Westernization that was completely wiping out cultures that have been around for thousands of years. Tribes in the rainforest now use cell phones and computers. The orient now has McDonalds. To me, Westernization is just a fancy way of saying "America subtly taking over". America is too full of itself, I said. America thinks that it doesn't need anyone. America thinks it IS the world. Of course, my thoughts were immediately and vehemently protested against, mainly by the male population who's testosterone levels were slowly but surely blocking blood-flow to their already undersized brains. "I'm glad we're bombing the shit out of them! They deserve it, the evil bastards!" "They bombed us, we should bomb them back!" "We're being generous-- giving them food. We shouldn't be doing that, fucking Iraqis." "Of course America's right. They're obviously wrong." Ladies and gentlemen, the future leaders of tomorrow. They were so gung-ho about going to war, they were like rednecks at a barbeque. Idiots. Fools. They don't know it won't be difficult to shoot someone your age. Someone just like you, wearing a different uniform but carrying the same gun. They don't know it won't kill them inside to take someone elses young life. They think it'll be just like the movies, all blood and gore and no guilty conscience or hesitance or fear. I'd like to see them in the heat of combat. I bet they'd change their tune mighty quick. I guess I wouldn't have been so appalled if these jerks were able to back up their opinions, but the only response I got to the debate was (and I QUOTE): "You're logic's stupid. My logic's smart." Good grief. I am disgusted with this. If my peers can't open their eyes for just a moment to see someone else's point of view, then we're all doomed to a miserable and wretched existence. WE ARE NOT GODS! WE DO NOT KNOW EVERYTHING, NOR CAN WE HAVE EVERYTHING! WE ARE NOT ALWAYS RIGHT! WE ARE NOT BETTER THAN ANYONE ELSE, WE ARE EQUAL ! To all of those who sacrificed something that September morning: Thank you. Thank you so very much for allowing me to see things I wouldn't have normally seen, thank you for allowing me to be a better person and to defend my beliefs. Thank you for helping me be humbled by the vastness of perception. Thank you.

"Love, I get so lost sometimes. Days pass, And this emptiness fills my heart..." ~ In Your Eyes , by Peter Gabriel Ahh, it feels great to be back home. Not that the wedding was awful, or anything-- it was very okay. But after spending three days with people you don't know who are 6+ years your senior, it's great to get back to the old routine. The trip was fine, I slept the majority of the 12 hour drive, so I really had nothing to complain about save the cramped leg-room and the constant old-people music. Ah well. Entering North Carolina had me experiencing mild cultural shock-- "y'all don' know 'bout red velvet cake?" (mmm, red velvet cake...) There were different wedding traditions (shorter than most, thank God), and lots of other stuff I didn't understand. We arrived Friday afternoon around 11:30, after getting lost for a half an hour we found our hotel-- conviniently located next to a Shell station (Gas is real cheap down south), an Applebees , and a Hooters . The room they gave us was nice and included cable, but sharing a room with my mom proved disasterous. Stupid neat freaks... There weren't many guests from the groom's (my cousin ^____^ Yay Bryan!) side of the family, so I was often left with a bunch of people I didn't know. It was rather uncomfortable. They pumped me on family issues and school and my social life, usually asking only after I'd taken a bite of dinner, of course. The pre-wedding atmosphere was unbearably tense, and everyone was so high strung I feared to say anything lest I set off a nuclear reaction. The wedding itself, however, ran smoothely-- the bride made everyone cry with her strange hybred of laughing and crying at the alter, and no one forgot any lines or fell over their skirts. On a sidenote, whoever invented high-heels should be shot >_____ The whole thing made me think, though. As I was witnessing a mile-stone in my cousin's life, if I would experience the same thing ten years down the line-- the frantic rehersals, the awkward kisses, electing bridesmaids and buying "the perfect dress", saying the "I do"s and pledging myself to one man 'till death do us part... Then I thought, ' Good God, I hope not .' I mean, what girl hasn't imagined herself in the dress, and having her friends as bridesmaids, and the beautiful ring on her left hand? Okay, okay, I confess that durring some of my more pathetic moments I dream of fantasy weddings and finding Mr. Right, but almost immediatly I trash the idea and berate myself for being so naive. Long ago, I'd made up my mind about a family of my own-- I don't want or need one. What's so great about pushing nine pounds of flesh and bones through your loins, catering to a drooly infant day and night, changing diapers, teaching them the lessons of life and basically becoming this dreaded tyrant of an adult... It sounds kind of like a permanent baby-sitting job to me, and I don't think I'd have the patience for it. It's not that I hate kids, I just dislike them. I've never really been one to think babies are cute-- I mean, they're wrinkly and pink and have huge heads and drool and are generally disgusting... however, voicing these opinions around many of my friends would result in a public beating... As for meeting a guy I'd even CONSIDER spending the rest of my life with... well, heh, good luck. I've been told I'm extremely picky when it comes to guys-- I want someone intelligent (a feat in itself), articulate and poetic, and he definately has to be funny. I couldn't stand to be around someone that didn't make me laugh at least once every day. "That's your problem, you don't want to be in love, you want to be in love in a movie." ~ Sleepless in Seattle Anyways, even if I found a guy like that (yeah right), I'd be wary about the whole wedlock thing. I mean, I can understand and tolerate infidelities in relationships, but marriage is something entirely different. A person promises that they'll have no other, and then the go and do it anyways? That's fucked up on so many levels. So, basically, I'm chained to this guy until death (I dissaprove of divorces). Does that thought scare the b'jeezus out of anyone else, or is it just me? Part of me, the part of me that's dreamed of a wedding ever since I was seven, thinks about elegant white dresses and finding true love. The other part, the cynic in me, believes that it's not possible, and that romanticized versions of love and marriage only serve to blind people as they grope about for stable pillars in their lives. My friends warn me that if this is the way I want my future to go, that I'm going to be all alone. That I'm going to die alone without experiencing "pure bliss". Whatever. I'm not worried about it-- I always have my friends to lean on when the going gets tough. And maybe, just fucking maybe , one day there'll be a guy that I love who'll be there to support me when I need it. Heh. I guess there's a little bit of a hopeless romantic in all of us, eh?

"If I died, would you shed tears of scarlet?" ~ Author unknown Arg, another crazy day. Mindlessly building yet another mountain of stress, I am. God, it's 9:00pm, and I have to be at my Uncle's at 10:00pm to start the drive down to North Carolina, and I'm not even packed. I hate missing school for things like this-- to tell the truth, I'd rather be in class, taking a math test instead of at a wedding a million miles away from my friends and around a bunch of uncomfortable relatives in numerous awkward situations. Hero of the day: Meghan, who's "Hero of the day" idea I shamelessly stole. I LOVE YOU, MEGHAN! ASIAN PRIDE! Adios, everyone. *Roars*

"Nightingale, sing us a song, Of a love that onced belonged. Nightingale, tell me your tale, Was your journey far too long?" ~ Nightingale by Norah Jones You know, one of these days I'm going to type a happy blog, and the universe will implode upon itself. We all go through them, and durring these short but horrid points in our lives, we all simply want to crawl under a rock an die. You know what I'm talking about. My life has been running me ragged as of late; AP/honors classes at school are driving me nuts, marching band (would you believe it?) is putting the pressure on, and I've been "hired" (I use the term loosely because I'm not quite sure if I'm actually getting paid...) to sing at my cousin's wedding. Not to say I'm not happy for them, but with all the other shit going on in my life, it seems like this is really on the lower-end of my list of priorities. I haven't listened to the music they want me to sing, and the wedding is this Saturday. Hooray for procrastination. Anyways, with my grandmother's death looming ever so close, I hate to leave... Besides, with all the school work piling up, I just don't know what to do. It's like God is conspiracing against me, and I'm about one more pop quiz away from having a nervous breakdown. But (Hah! You thought I'd be completely pessamistic, didn't you?) I have found a hero for the day: My good buddy, Brad. Now, I'm not going into messy details, but Brad's been going through some rough spots in his own life-- emotional stuff that I'd rather not get into. For the past few days, he's been walking around like a zombie; dark rings under his eyes and a stoic expression so out of character for someone as generally happy as he. It was unnerving to see him so upset, and I tried everything just to coax a smile out of him, when normally he'd make me laugh over the smallest things. However, being a leader in our marching band, Brad had to suck it up. Being a drum major, the band reflected his moods. We depended on him. Because of this, he was forced to pretend (and damn, can that boy act) that he really wasn't suffering from intense emotional turmoil. He had to fake smiles and jokes and laughs I know didn't breach the skin-- all for the sake of something as trivial as high school marching band. And so, I dedicate this entire (however short) post to Brad, my hero for the day. And for all of you wishing that some meteor would fall from the sky and plow you into the ground, don't worry. You aren't alone, and things will get better eventually. "Whatever happens, happens." Spike, Cowboy Bebop. And that's all I have to say about that.

"I don't know the key to success, but the key to failure is to try to please everyone." ~Bill Cosby Ack. Just... ack. Do you ever get the feeling that your internal rhythm is off? My life feels horribly out of balance-- one minute swinging just within the barest scraps of comfort and security before crashing out and sending me back into this funk of blah-ness. It's like I've built my tower way too high and now it's wobbling precariously, eventually preparing to throw all the blocks directly at my head... Most of the time I'm generally happy, bouncy, energetic, etc. However, the tiniest, most insignificant things often throw my entire system out of whack, making me one Hell of a moody bitch. I've experienced more moodswings in the past three days than I have in what seems like my entire adolescence. And, quite frankly, I hate it. I'm not even sure why things are happening anymore; it all seems completely out of my hands. You know what else I hate? The feeling that I'm not in control of my own life. Right now, I feel like I'm just barely hanging on for the ride. One minute, things seem bearable-- school's peachy and people are too. The next, however-- life's kicking my ass again, school's overwhelming, and people are spreading their depression like a disease. Eh. Must be all those teenage hormones or something just swinging me from one extreme to the other. As far as I'm concerned, high school is still just some glorified, romanticized version of elementary school, and people make way too big of a deal out of it. This may sound a bit hypocritical of me to say, but really, in the big picture high school is just a (sometimes) fond memory, and life does go on outside of it. People often seem to forget that, myself included. Blah. Sorry about all the above crap. I just needed to get that out before I blew up. Rant over, let's get to what's going on in my life: ~I've been sick for the past few days-- my head has felt like I've been wearing anchors for earrings and my stomach feels like it's trying to turn itself inside out. Cherries from Hell, maybe...) just to get through the day. End of story. ~Everyone's uncomfortably edgy at home. The parents have decided to buckle down on my brother and I, taking away privileges at the drop of a hat. This has resulted in several angry and violent disputes, which have not yet been resolved. Tensions continue to rise, and its really starting to get to me. ~Drama's gathering steam, slowly but surely. The musical is going to rock, and I can't wait to see the finished product. Everyone's working so hard to get things to run smoothly, and it's not hard to see that the effort is really going to pay off in the long run. It'll be the first play in the new auditorium, and I am extremely excited to be using this professional theater to bring the production to life. ~I'm receiving a 'D' in math. The first almost-failing-grade I've ever gotten, and it's really unnerving. I mean, this is junior year, the most important year of all-- the year that the colleges look for, the last year that I'll have to put any effort into anything... But, in short: math sucks, period. ~A good friend of mine came over today and we had a nice, long chat. I'm glad she's feeling at least a little bit better; she really had me freaked out for the past couple of weeks with her no-talking-no-eating thing. But you know? Whatever. "C'est la vie". I'm fine. Just give me a few days to organize the chaos in my life and things will get better. A person can't be unhappy all the time, right? Right....

"I don't want a thing from you, But you're tired of me Waiting for the scraps to fall off of your table To the ground..." ~ Breathing , Lifehouse I was happy. I was so happy but, damnit, I couldn't hold onto it. He said he likes me. He likes me. Those words meant the world to me, and I felt completely full for just a dazzling second in the massive expanse of time. It was as if I had everything I needed even if everything itself wasn't perfect. I grinned like an idiot for over a day, replaying his words in my head on a constant loop and floating higher and higher each time. I felt whole. He likes me. And, God, there is no doubt in my mind that I like him. But... I simply don't know anymore. We don't really know how to act around each other anymore. He's got stuff in his mind to clear up and I have insecurities to get over before anything can actually happen, and in this space of time I think that maybe... I get this fear in the back of my heart... It chokes me from the inside out-- and old phobia, you could call it. Will his feelings still stay strong come tomorrow? Or the next day? I fear that he may get bored with me, or that he might find someone better. It would be so easy for him to, because he's this amazing person and I'm no prize. Now that I have his attention, how on Earth will I be able to keep it? The last guy in my life soon grew tired of me and sought better company, leaving me to wonder what it was that drove him off. Will history repeat itself and leave me broken again? Every fiber of my being is praying to whatever super-natural powers listening that it won't. I tell myself it won't, it won't, it won't... But there's always the doubt buried in my heart.... And also, as if I didn't feel cruddy enough as it was... Some of the people closest to my heart have reached this extremely depressed state of mind-- I feel so useless not knowing the problem or how to solve it. They won't talk to me, and its tearing me apart just waiting on the sidelines for the storm to pass. It's like I'm on the other side of a wall too high to breach and too thick to penetrate; like there's some cosmic secret that I'm not being let in on. It hurts to watch these people deteriorate before my eyes, shriveling down to empty husks of human beings, withdrawn and alone. How can I make you see that you AREN'T alone? That you don't HAVE to keep it all inside? My arms are open and will always be. I don't know what to do. I don't know what to do . I have all the pieces in my hands, but I can't get it to work... And just like that, cloud 9 dropped about 8 clouds. I try to stay upbeat, put on a brave face and act oblivious to the sadness that seems to thicken the air like a stale fog, but I'm fumbling for masks. I even allowed pride to escape me for a fleeting moment and did something I vowed never to do, and still they were not moved. You know, for the first time in what feels like forever, I felt significant. But now, it's like I'm not important enough to see or stop the invisible blade killing the people I love from the inside out. I try-- God, I try... But it's never any use. I wind up back at square one feeling more battered than before. Damn, I really need a hug right now... You want to know why? I'm tired of getting pushed away.

"It's a masterful melody when she calls out my name to me; As the world spins around her she laughs, rolls her eyes, And I feel like I'm falling, but it's no surprise 'Cause I love her with all that I am And my voice shakes along with my hands, 'Cause it's frightening to be swimming in a strange sea But I'd rather be here than on land..." ~ Out of My League by Stephen Speaks As hard as I tried to keep this blog from becoming extremely sappy with my personal life, I have to speak what I feel before I blow up from keeping it bottled up. Be warned: major sap coming up, and I shall most likely make myself seem like an infatuated idiot, completely twisting around my disenchanted attitude into something almost pathetically optimistic. I feel spectacular. I feel choking amounts of anxiety and hesitance, I feel unsure and self-concious, but at the same time I feel open and unrestrained-- the fact that I feel anything all after being so numb for such a long time still amazes me. Even with the heavy doses of fear and timidness, it's such a relief to be filled. I can only compare it to waking up and finding out that you can sleep for another hour-- it's a warm feeling that I can barely remember. (Bah! So corny!) There are times when all I can do is smile stupidly... ... And who would have thought the cause of this explosion of emotion would be due to some guy... That's right, you heard me. Me, the cynic. Me, the bitter wench. I've finally found someone to think about, someone sweet and funny, someone who's just what I need. Sure, he's not perfect or anything, but I love the way he makes me feel-- like I matter. Now before you get ahead of yourself, I know I'm not in love, I don't think... I've been in love, but this is something different. I think it's just a strong crush. A very strong crush. I don't get to see him a lot, but when I do I feel like my heart can put the fastest racehorse to shame (corny, yes. Painfully so.) He's this wonderful person whom I've never really noticed until recently. I feel uncharacteristically shy, he makes me blush for no reason at all, and I fumble for words and become this ditzy thirteen-year-old. Needless to say, I make an ass out of myself around him. But I really don't care. I mean, as far as I know, he enjoys my company when we're able to get together, and despite the disappointingly little opportunities we have for private conversation, I think he trusts me. I miss him when we can't arrange a meeting, and get excited when we can. I even primp in front of the mirror, for godsake. Good God, what have I become?!?! Someone take note: This post will most likely be taken down from sheer embarrassment and fear that someone might work out who I'm writing about, thus exposing the secret to the world to my chagrin. Ah, listen to me. I would have never thought that ANYONE would get me to spout this sort of idiocy again. Once was more than enough-- I'd had my heart trampled all over, anyways, the damn bastard. (If I ever find that sleazy S.O.B again I'm going to make sure he never has children.) Anyways, this guy's the best thing that's happened to me in years-- a guy my parents would approve of, a guy I like being around, a guy that never makes me feel unimportant. I'm falling hard, but I'm loving every moment of it. (God, corny line #8...) But, sadly, the chances of a fairytale ending are slim to none. You see, no matter what I do, I'll never be able to replace the person he's already placed in his heart. And, quite frankly, I don't want to. I don't want to compete with someone I could never measure up to. And despite my feelings for him (which--I assume-- are obvious, especially to him.), I doubt I'd ever be thought of as more than a fond friend. He's way too... Well, himself... And me, well.... You get the idea. It would never work anyways. Heh, tell that to my stupid heart. Obviously, it has issues, and cannot listen to reason. But, you know, whatever. Despite the hopelessness of my little crush, I'm enjoying it. I love feeling what I'm feeling, even if everything is unrequited. I'll do what I can to gain his attention, because that's all I can possibly do; and I'll float in childish euphoria when he says my name, and sigh wistfully behind his back, and go all stupid and spacy whenever I think of him (I'm such a loser ^___^). "Yes, she's all that I see and she's all that I need, And I'm out of my league once again..."

"I sit here on my shelf, Just talking to myself, Words that we couldn't say..." ~ Words We Couldn't Say , The Seatbelts Is it wrong to think of your own home as a prison? I'm so sick of staring at these walls-- unchanging and sallow. I've never felt so bored with myself, like I can't do anything worth while. Nothing amuses me-- not TV, not drawing... I've hit some sort of mental block and it's frustrating me to no end. Lately I've been so restless, wandering up and down the hallways, staring longingly out the window, and keeping an ear open to the phone in case it rings with some invitation to the outside world. In case none of you can read my subtle hints, I'm grounded. My mother returned from her second trip to Florida yesterday morning (where we're digging up the money to fund these trups, I have no idea). Needless to say, I wasn't exactly looking foreward to the arrival. You see, my mother was never one for sensitivity. There was no "Hey, guys, it's good to see you," or "Hi, Emilee; yeah, I missed you too," or "I'm glad to be home! What have you guys been up to?" There was only "God, this house is such a mess. I can't even come home to a clean house; you always leave everything out, Emilee," and "your brother tells me you've been bullying him. You need to appologize for that-- I don't know where you learned your mannors." Apparently I'm being punished on the grounds of my poor behavior towards my mother's return. Ah well. It's just how she is, I suppose. Buisnesslike and stern. She expects perfection, and sees no reason as to why her expectations are never met. She likes store-bought presents over handmade ones (needless to say, she didn't like the drawing I made her for her birthday. She said it was a tacky idea to give someone a picture in place of a gift).... she's just proper like that, I guess. Whatever. She makes me fear two things: Becoming the person who failed at everything.... ... And becoming her. Anyways, I really should stop complaining. I hate it when I complain... it makes me feel like some whiny-13-year-old-drama-queen. For the most part, life has me feeling suprisingly apathetic towards everything, maybe even content. I've accepted the bad stuff, and enjoy the good stuff (mmm... good stuff....), I really don't see any reason to be upset. I'm young, I have at least 70 more years to get through, I should do my best to feel my best. So, I've treated myself to late night television, second helpings on my mom's German chocolate cake, overdoses of leftover Holloween candy, and an extended Christmas list. All in all, despite whatever miniscule discrepencies I have now, the thought that these problems will seem laughable in a few years makes me feel much better. Laughing usually does. So I'll just wait until I can laugh. P.S. The snow's here... Snow = sledding + ice skating + snowmen + igloos! *joy*

"Whatever happens, happens." ~Spike Spiegel, Cowboy Bebop Forget driving myself out of my head trying to figure things out, forget the late night caucus races my worries have been running, and forget the insane juggling act I've been franticly trying to perform to keep my blocks from falling-- urlLink I give up.

"I will go down with this ship-- And I won't put my hands up and surrender. There will be no white flag above my door. I'm in love, And always will be..." ~ White Flag , Dido Trying to get my life back in order is one hell of a task. First off all, picking up the shattered fragments of all I tried so hard to keep from breaking makes me sick to my stomach. It's one ugly mess, I can assure you. Two deaths in a month... It brings hot tears to my eyes just thinking about it. Recently, my other grandma down in Florida passed away. It wasn't something that I really felt like talking about, and I didn't break down again, but dealing with grieving parents was something I really wasn't looking forward to for the second time this month. My mother left for Florida a week ago and returned yesterday, leaving me alone with my still-off father. Not yet having recovered from his own mother's death, he was hard to live with-- I was often caught off guard with "why can't you kids do anything without breaking something?!" and "you idiot! Don't do that!" and "God damnit, can't you do ANYTHING right?!" Needless to say, it was a long week. I figured that when my mom came home, life would return to as normal as it would get... Dad would stop yelling, I'd have someplace to hide, and I could begin piecing myself back together. However, I was horribly mistaken. The first thing my mother did when she stepped in the door was make a snide comment on how poorly we had taken care of the house, then preceded to bitch me out for not keeping our home clean. Since the moment she came home, all she's done is make me feel like I'm incompetent. Just one kick after another. But I can handle this. I won't complain or cry. It has to go away sometime, and when it does we can all be happy... Please, God, just let us be happy.... ******************************************************************** He wants me to run. To where, I have no idea. But I'm supposed to run away. Does he really want me out of his life that badly? Am I that much of a burden? From what he tells me, it's mostly for my own protection against a hurt that is "destined to come", but it doesn't make what he says any easier to swallow. I don't know how to make things better-- it's my call, but I'm damned either way. If I run, it'll just be one more thing I've taken the cowardly easy way out on. If I stick it out, I risk making the situation worse and possibly hurting someone I care about so, so, so much. Not much of an ultimatum, if you ask me. I don't want to run; I'm sick of running away from all the hurdles in my life. But he wants me to. I just can't understand. Sometimes I think he may have a point, that maybe it's not worth it. I wish that I wasn't falling so hard for him, and, in my weakest and most pathetic moments, almost hope for my feelings to dissipate. Often afterwards, I give myself a mental slap-in-the-face because it was a stupid thought to think. It's hard to make an unbiased decision when his arms are encircling my waist and his heartbeat is under my palm. I don't know what to do. It makes me dizzy and heartsick to think about. To him, if he is reading, I hope that I'm not causing you pain by not heeding your warnings. If I am, that is not and never was my intent. But I can't bring myself to run just now. I have nowhere to go. To him, you're not a horrible person. I may just be a masochist, not your fault. You will never be a horrible person to me. To him, as I've told you before, I'm lost because I don't know where I'm going... Only where I've been. To him, I think I might love you. I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

"Four more exits to my apartment, But I am tempted to keep the car in drive And leave it all behind...." Why Georgia by John Mayer Today was just not my day, I guess. Very few are, actually-- but I digress. Woke up this morning at 10:30AM for a doctor's appointment (God, I am the equivalent to the human petri dish...), and just felt like the whole world was coming down on my head. I don't know what it was about today, but there was this anxiety, this anger building in my chest that made me want to lash out at everything.... as if everything were contributing to my misery. I couldn't walk a straight line, or even put together a coherent thought-- my whole being felt so fragile, but it seemed to be mistaken as a grouchy mood. Every time I was scolded or my mother rolled her eyes at me or my brother called me a jerk or my dad heaved a frustrated sigh, my heart sunk lower and lower. I tried not to let it get to me, but failed miserably. Quite frankly, I don't know quite how to deal with anger. I can't let it out through my art, because if the image is ever found I'll be carted back to counseling. I can't cry, because part of me is too damn proud to cry, wallowing in self-pity. I can't really vent, because I'm never sure what sets me off in the first place. As a result of this emotional constipation, I end up all bitchy and pissy, snapping and becoming extremely defensive over the smallest issues. I want to break stuff and rip the world apart. I don't know. Self-control never was my forte. Today we visited my dad's store, Tuesday Mornings , bargain shopping for last-minute gifts. No one asked for me, no one spoke to me. I was left alone and quickly forgotten amidst the fully stocked isles of rugs and kitchenwear and what have you. So, I wandered. Most of the shelves were packed with boring living supplies-- pots and pans, tupperwear, cleaning supplies... But something about one of the isles close to the end of the store made me stop. The shelves up and down on both sides were stocked to the max with painted glass vases, elegant crystal champagne glasses, white porcelain bowls and china plates, and glass candle holders. The entire isle glittered; everything was out and open and so extremely vulnerable. The moment I set foot inside that fragile tunnel my mind slapped me with a scenario-- I saw myself letting loose an anguished cry and attacking the shelves, wiping them clean of their expensive burdens. All of my frustration, all of my anger and tears were reflected in the sound of breaking glass. Flawless goblets fell in slow motion and shattered with an emphasized crash, bursting into a million sparkling pieces. My arms flew out ahead of me, my hands making quick work of the expensive dishes; rampantly, I threw them down by the armload to be pleasured by the satisfying sound they made when they hit the ground. And then, when the shelves were clear and all the bowls and vases and glasses and plates were shattered beyond recognition, I went back down the isle, grinding the sharp fragments into the linoleum tile under the heel of my foot. I kicked at those pieces, stomped on them, turned them into powder and wrote my name in them-- the sound of breaking glass ringing in my ears. But the second I blinked, the glasses had been reassembled and were sitting in neat little rows according to size and price. The vases were aligned next to the primly-stacked china plates, the bowls and chandelier arms sparkled perfectly under the fluorescent lights. Everything was as it should be. In that instant, my heart broke with disappointment. I feel like I'm losing myself, I need something to bring me back to life. I'm in the mood to sulk-- I don't know if I have the energy or the stamina to stay angry for very long. I don't even know what I'm angry at. The world? My family? Myself? I'm in the mood to take a long walk off a short cliff. And I don't like that at all. I hate not being strong enough to take this, I hate how much I want to just give up. I hate how I can't fix myself, because I know I am broken in some way, and I hate not being able to know just WHY I've sunk this low. Listen to me. What an ugly hypocrite I've turned out to be. I hate me.

"Myr is mine; it's bitter perfume, Tells a tale of gathering gloom, Sorrowing, sighing, bleeding, dying, Sealed in a stone-cold tomb..." "Cause you're living in a fantasy world Taking your time, running your mind on low. You're living in a fantasy land, Holding no one's hand but your own..." Water , Jason Mraz I'm not okay. I'm the last to admitt it, but I do admitt that I am not okay. The days are fluctuating in speed, racing raggedly until it slows to a snail's pace, before stopping time all together. I go through the movements of my normal routine without any hindrence, but they're all empty. I can't smile without feeling the familiar churn in my stomach. But for the most part, I fool people. It's not really that hard; people are stupid. I slap on the happy face and swallow my unsettled emotions. I want to die. I really want to die. But, alas (or luckily, whichever you choose) I am an enormous coward, and so the only thing keeping me tied to this horrid existance is my extreme fear of death itself. I can only pray for some freak accident to happen at any given moment, snuffing me out. Everything seems so overwhelming-- I just feel like I'm not enough sometimes, it's choking and consuming and I don't know what to do. Instead of just running its course and dissipating, the sadness is turning into anger, which I don't know how to deal with. I just want to break down and break up and explode, but I can't afford to let myself go. I'd promised myself that I'd never cry because of self-pity. I broke that promise today, and because of that I know something is horribly wrong. Today I cried for the first time since my grandma died. I'm so ashamed of those bitter tears, I couldn't stop them. I cried and sobbed and hiccupped until I had to take myself outside into the snow to calm down before someone came home and saw me; we can't have a little sibling see his sister so unstable, or have mother come home and see her daughter so derranged. No one saw me. No one knows how pathetic I am, or else it'd just add one more bullet to the growing list of my flaws. I can't even cry without being worried to screw someone else up. God, I hate myself. It was only this bad once before, and I'd hate for the reprocussions of that time to come back to haunt me now. I don't know why it's so bad or why I can't get over it, but it's formed a pill too large for me to swallow, let alone stomach. I don't like the idea of waking up in the morning and wishing I didn't. It just doesn't sit well with me. My entire world seems to be imploding on itself-- I'm sinking and clawing for solid ground, but the strong pillars in my life have suddenly crumbled with problems of their own. There's no where to turn or to go, there's nothing to hold on to. I miss my friends, before they became as lost as I am. I just want to give up. But I won't let myself. When I was crying earlier today, I drew a picture, trying to relieve the pressure my anger and anguish and frustration was putting on my mind. Looking at it now, I question myself so much-- it's almost as if I don't know what I'm capable of anymore. The drawing is far more abstract than my usual work, and it's full of black and red and orange with cramped cursive writing and nonsense phrases covering the oddest portions of the paper. There's a cross in the upper left corner, followed by the words: "Don't let the world miss you." I don't know what that means. To tell the truth, I don't know much of anything these days. I just kind of let myself drift along, while I rot from the inside out. Some part of me is dying-- I can feel it-- but I don't know how to stop it. I don't want help, I just don't know what it is I want from people. People often get really nosy, offering hollow promises to "be there for you" if you ever wanted to talk. What fair-weather idiots. I don't want to talk to just anyone, I don't want anyone else to make the problem go away; I have to do it myself. All I can ask from everyone else is support. I need support to keep myself from sinking any lower and going under. Hug me. Please. If I can just hold together for one more night, I'll have plenty of days to fall apart and put myself back together again in peace. Un rapido noche, por favor, por favor.... Adios, mi amor.

"Another day where I can't find my head, My feet don't look like they're my own. I try to find the floor below to stand; I hope I reach it once again..." ~ Feelin' the Same Way , Norah Jones I'm so ready for something good. Lately I've been feeling direction-less... Because I've stayed home for the past three days due to strep throat (what a horrible, horrible virus), I'm so far behind on my schoolwork that it makes me want to scream and rip my hair out. But I doubt I could feel it anyways, what with the plethora of anti-biotics and painkillers I've been taking to try and ward off the sore throat and coughing and fever. I get so annoyed with myself for staying home, though, because I'd much rather go to school and visit with my friends. I miss them so much when I'm by myself. My dad, when he stays home, takes pains to ignore me, and my mom is teaching little monkeys of second graders for the majority of the day, so it's just me, all by my lonesome. Anyways, sometimes I get kind of worried staying out of the social loop for an extended period of time. The whole "out of sight, out of mind" mantra drives me crazy, and I really don't like the idea of being quickly forgotten or replaced. Not that I really have anything to worry about; my friends are the greatest. Arynn, Meghan, and Brad came over to visit me the first day I was sick. I wasn't expecting them to drop by, so I was preoccupied with a rather pleasant nap when Arynn started wailing on my bedroom window with her fist (we have no doorbell, and I'd turned the ringer off of my phone so those damn solicitors wouldn't bother me). Anyways, after groggily managing to stagger upstairs and unlock the front door, the crew paraded in, carrying four newly-purchased bags of ramen noodles. They'd even managed to buy two bags of chicken flavored noodles and two bags of beef flavored noodles so they could make bicken ramen, my favorite kind (chicken + beef = bicken). Brad eagerly invaded the kitchen, nearly catching the house on fire trying to boil the water (*snickers*). Arynn and Meghan sat with me, catching me up on what I'd missed that day. We laughed a lot, mostly at Brad's expense, but it was all in good fun. It felt good to laugh, even though it was quite a task in my congested state. Once the noodles were done, we all grabbed a bowl and dug in. They were a little overcooked, but still very good, and I was so flattered that they'd even taken the time to make it for me. Brad even did the dishes. It's the stuff like that... stuff like that always makes me feel so guilty for ever doubting the quality of my life. No one had ever visited me while I was sick before, let alone cooked me one of my favorite meals. It was such a sweet thing for them to do, and it was probably the highlight of my month. Thanks, guys. I love you. As for the other four days between my last post and this one, my world's been pretty dumpy. I've been feeling really down, but I just can't figure out why. Maybe it's the sickness... It's hard to stay optimistic when you can't breathe through your nose. My parents are irritated with me again, but that's no surprise. I've been missing more school than usual, and they're concerned about my grades. What bothers me is that they're not as concerned about my health . I guess I'm just feeling the weight of things recently. Ah, well. A girl's gotta learn to suck it up if she ever expects to survive the real tragedies. This is Emilee, signing off.

There's a lot of running involved, and I have neither the strength nor the endurance to fufill the required quota for warm-up runs and mile runs and shuttle runs... Running ties my abdominal muscles into so many knots it's unbelievable. I come home sore in so many places-- I get achy muscles in muscles I didn't even know I had. Been thinking about what I want to do for the rest of my life... It's still a little fuzzy, but I'm starting to feel more comfortable with the mystery. I can do what I want, it might take a while, but I'll be able to do it eventually. There's always a way, the only thing that can stop me is myself. Besides, who knows what other options and opportunities may present themselves over the course of my young life? I can hardly wait to get out in the world, and really find out about myself. It'll be an adventure, one of my first. It's late. I probably won't get a chance to update until we get a new, faster computer (someday soon, me thinks). So until then, goodnight.

Then I'd collect the smashed pottery and the smashed meat pasties and grind them into all my perfect stitchery." ~ Ella Enchanted , authored by Gail Carson Levine It's snowing to put the North Pole to shame. Not only is there over a foot of snow weighing down our roofs, but there's a windchill low enough to freeze spit before it hit the ground. I'm beginning to look forward to spring... Last night, I went over to Arynn's house with Meghan and Josh, and we basically just hung around watching TV. It was great fun. Josh taught us how to send text-messages to Meghan's cell phone via Aol Instant Messenger, and we nearly short-circuted her phone by rapidly sending 500 messages of nonsense (Arynn sent the entire alphabet, with each letter as a seperate message). Later that night, Meghan and I got to talking, and I was surprised to learn that she wasn't planning on voting even though sufferage allowed her to. You know, for the first time in my life I actually feel strongly about the political status of our country. For years, politics were extremely boring, but now I want so badly to be 18; I want to vote. I mean, this year I actually know which party I support (I'm pro-choice in almost all situations), and I would lop of my right hand if it ensured that Bush wouldn't spend another term in office. I really want to be a part of this decision, and it burns me up that my voice wont be heard for another few years. But anyways, enough of politics. I'm probably boring you with them anyways. I know most teenagers hate their legal guardians, but when I say I hate my mother I mean I loathe her. There's no given time in the day when I'm okay with her-- she can't look at me without saying something to intentionally piss me off. I mean, I love her in a 'you-raised-me-so-I-have-to' kind of way, but if she were someone else's mom, I'd be depicting her eminant doom in extremely bloody pictures. Yay. I'm bitching again. I'm sick of being under her thumb, and I'm sick of being so afraid to stand up for myself and stop taking all of her bull shit. Her mind's so twisted and contorted around the concept of a perfect child... I can never obtain the image of flawnessness that she wants. And it's all about image, my friend. If I look sloppy or stupid, I make HER look sloppy or stupid. She dictates everything. How I wear my hair, how I dress-- she'd decide who my friends were if I let her. She wants me to do well, but no matter how well I do it's always sub-par. I can't tell if her expectations are impossibly over my capabilities or if she expects me to fail. Looking back, it seems we've come a long way, even if we're no where close to having a decent relationship; I remember when she'd parade me around her work like a show dog, and I remember how threatened I'd feel when I get a B on a test. I was completely submissive, and she controled every aspect of my life. Not anymore, thank God, but we've still got a long way to go. One of my favorite novels is called Ella Enchanted, by Gail Carson Levine. It's about a girl under a fairy's spell that makes her completely obedient-- if someone gives her an order, she has to obey, no matter what the consequences. I've read it hundereds of times, and lately I find myself drawn to it again, despite its simplicity. I feel better reading it, because it has a happy ending. Ah well. There's nothing anyone can do for me concerning this particular topic, but it soothes my mind to think that someone out there might understand. So yes, mother. I agree with you. I am a bitch. I might fail as an adult. I might remain an idiot for the rest of my life. I may not ever be able to take care of myself. I might always be worthless. But I do know one thing: I will never be you. And at the end of the day that will always be true. Do you think living happily ever after happens in reality? Today I'm meeting up with a bunch of my Korean buddies, some of which I haven't spoken to in over a year. We've grown apart, even though we vowed never to. I feel like I've remained very much the same in my intrests, but my friends have moved on from horses to boys and cars. Today should be pretty interesting. I hope we can find some common ground to talk over for a few hours. I'm breaking the rules by sneaking onto the internet with my mother's computer. I'd better go before she finds me and reminds me once again why my future is doomed to fail. So, on this note, I'll leave you with something I wrote a while ago but found and edited today: "G-e-I-g-R-g-L Shells" She bows politely and lowers her eyes, She?ll be a good girl today. She'll swallow the spitfire And drown the monster That is she. Never again will she yell, Or raise her voice in protest. Instead, She lays out the napkins, neatly folded With the forks and knives tucked inside. She?ll be a good girl today. Because her mother told her she has a beautiful voice Only when her mouth is closed.

"Nobody likes me. Everybody hates me. Guess I'll go eat worms." Once upon a time, in a place not too far from the ocean but very far from here, there was a pond. Murky and small, it lay in the dip of two dirty hills, collecting old rainwater and whatever debris floated down from the nearby city. Swampy weeds turned its bottom into mush, while bacteria coated its surface with thick algae; the scent of rotting wood and stale water hung in the air between the hills. Despite the dark, monotonous sky that hovered overhead, the grasses surrounding the body of water soon shriveled and died, for the ominous clouds never brought rain. Very few creatures could stand to live in such a polluted environment-- a few toads, many creepy-crawly insects, and a handful of small, bottom-dwelling fish were all that habited the pond and its shores. Scruffy-looking birds, when desperate enough, would sometimes venture near the edges of the water to catch the meager grubs that burrowed along the bank. However, unbeknownst to the casual passerby, one old fish swam in the shallow end of the pond, his dorsal fin skimming the surface and disturbing the greening water. Small and the color of mud, he had lived out many a year at the dank silt bottom of the pool. In his prime, he had been feisty and lively, taunting the birds by leaping clear out of the water and smacking the water with a loud splash! Now in his old age, the mud-brown fish had begun to tire, his scales no longer sleek and his body unable to do much other than sleep; he was content to simply warm himself on the dirty sand and dream. Dream of open water. Oh, he had heard stories; the little fish once had a very awkward conversation with an old swallow (the swallow was far too emaciated and close to death to be a threat to his life). The bird had weaved tales of water so big that no creature ever found the other side. Tales of magnanimous proportion, fish the size of trees and birds with gills. Trapped within the confines of his tiny watery prison, the mud-brown fish would often imagine a daring escape and a long swim in the big water that would last the rest of his life. His friends, grown cynical with age, scoffed at the ridiculousness of the idea. Water expanding until the sun rose from its surface? Even if such a place did exist, they pointed out, how on earth did the mud-brown fish intend on getting to it? Fly? It was impossible, they said. And even still, the little old fish dreamed. He dreamed and dreamed until the sun had set a thousand times and the autumn turned to winter turned to spring. And now, he was a very old fish. His eyes were beginning to cloud and he was going blind; his scales had dulled from mud-brown to grey; his muscles, once feathery and strong, had become stringy and limp-- swimming became an exercise. The old fish knew he soon would die... And he would never have lived anywhere other than this tiny, polluted pond. But then-- miracles of miracles-- it began to rain. For the first spring in his lifetime, the pond rippled with raindrops pouring from the over-saturated clouds and coming down in sheets, in buckets. It rained and rained and rained for an entire month, quickly filling the little pond until it overflowed and a small stream leaked the access water out to the east. Birds, frogs, rabbits, even a few deer, all healthy and spirited, ventured near the dirty little pond-- the rain had rejuvinated the land and made it habitable for all sorts of creatures, not just a last desperate resort to dying beasts. The tiny inlet was a door thrown wide. Many younger, spryer, more adventurous fish left the pond without a second thought, traveling with the weak current to wherever the stream led. The very old fish, once mud-brown, remained in the shallows where he could rest his weary fins on the warm sand. 'Maybe when I were younger,' he thought to himself with a sigh, 'I could have made the journey. But I am an old fish, and soon will die.' Days passed, and the little fish remained where he lay, feeling miserable and growing older and closer to death. Even though the door to the open water was right in front of him, the very old fish was too weary and ancient to move from his spot. His friends laughed at him. Grown older themselves, they too were too old to make the journey and were thus left behind. 'Go,' they goaded, 'you wanted so badly to leave that you wasted your life wishing.' 'Maybe if I had wished harder,' the very old fish replied tiredly, 'I could have made the journey. But I am a very old fish, and soon will die.' To this they laughed. 'If wishes were fishes every bird and snake and toad would be full...' At this the old fish fell silent and spoke no more for the rest of his life. The very old fish, once mud-brown now grey and closer to death than he ever thought possible, spent the remainder of his days lingering around the opening to the ever-shrinking inlet; without more continuous rainfall, the stream was drying up. He lazily swam the length of the mouth endlessly, wondering what became of those who had taken it, his body becoming sicker and sicker with age and the inlet becoming smaller and smaller with the day's heat. The day the pond finally closed to trap the very old fish within, he died. The very old fish had awoken in the morning to find the stream completely gone. He was so heartbroken that he used the last ounce of his thinning strength to thrash around violently, speaking his upset without words or tears. A starving bird, upon seeing the disturbance in the water, quickly took to flight... ... and in the stillborn hours of the morning, gobbled up the very old, dying fish without hesitation. The end.

"Suppose I said: I am on my best behavior, And there are times I lose my worried mind..."~ Not Myself , John Mayer (THANK GOD I FOUND ROOM FOR SQUARES !!) Well. It's been a while since I put forth the effort toward a real post, but I've had a lot on my mind.. I'm going to try to use this thing as more of a journal from now on; semi-public or not, I just want to come clean. Please, if you do read this, just leave it alone. I don't need sympathy or crude advice. I just need someone to listen. There's been so much shit happening... I wake up in the morning after a few scant hours of sleep and try to operate as normally as possible. I go to school, tired as hell and ready to burst into a million pieces, when I remember that no one wants to see me being such a pathetic baby, so I slap on a smile and go about my merry way. I take the tests, I lose the assignments, I struggle for the grades and come home completely exhausted. I hate parading around like a polished human being when inside I'm just a mess. When I get back, I am welcomed by a house that's sucking up money faster than my parents can make it, arguments between my parents over trivial things like lost money and relatives, more people close to me getting sick and going to the hospital, punishment because of stupid mistakes, and everyone pressuring me to fix my fucked-up future. I feel so helpless and stranded; I cry a lot, even in school when no one's watching. No one ever sees. The few hours I have to just sit back and relax are fleeting. I feel like a wire stretched taught and being wound tighter and tighter-- everything in me seems on the brink of snapping and I just can't find a way around it. Suppressing the anxieties that plague me has been my main objective for the past few weeks, and for the most part I've got people fooled into thinking it's nothing but a bad day. But I think that deep down, I know it's only a matter of time before everything falls apart again and all my nerves are exposed. Tests and grades and chores and money and jobs and arguments and fathers not coming home until the wee hours of the morning... it's been a lot to swallow. And because of this, I've done some things I'm so ashamed of... Have I screwed everything up for good? Brad's come to my aid a few times, lounging around with me and offering whatever support he can. He doesn't know it, but it's a blessing when he comes to rescue me from myself for a few hours. It's been wonderfully stress-relieving, but as soon as he goes home I'm thrust back into reality that I'm not always sure I can handle. I hate being so dependant on him, because I know I'll be alone soon and he won't be there to be my crutch. When my parents have a big fight (which has been happening much more often), my dad will simply drive away. I fear that he might go to a bar, get drunk, and drive home-- so I stay up until he gets home to help him into bed and make sure he made it home in one piece. This is probably the most exhausting part of my life-- I get so scared. I don't want to confront him about it, because I don't want him to feel that he's not doing his part as a father, especially when he's having so many problems with my mom. I just want him to stick around and not get himself in trouble. I need him still, and it wouldn't do at all if he lets go too early. God, can't I even reflect without weeping like a moron? I really have to stop crying. It's pathetic... Stephen's over, planning to test out our family by spending the night. I guess he's trying to break into the change gradually. He's a cool kid-- surprisingly mature and so very nice. Stevie is 8 years old and in the 4th grade. His mother is a drug addict and he doesn't have a father. He and his brother live with is grandmother, who is in a wheelchair. Steve's older brother is going to be institutionalized for crimes I can't even fathome for one so young; he steels Steve cigarettes and God only knows what else. Anyways, the state is taking Stephan from his fucked-up family and giving him to a foster home. My mom offered to take him-- he being one of her old students-- and have him live with us for the rest of the school year and maybe part of the summer. Change is a scary thing, I guess. But I never had any idea how scary it would be for me . Sure, I'm psyched that we're having him and such... but part of me is kind of leery of him. I know I shouldn't be, because he's just a kid and everything. Yet there's something-- maybe it?s sympathy, maybe it's suspicion-- either way I feel so uncomfortable. I feel like one of my last refuges, however small, has been taken away. I have to be Susie-Sunshine in the morning, at school, and now at home. I can't go out as much to escape the madness and pressure because I'll have to baby-sit. But that only makes me a selfish jerk. God, what is wrong with me? I want to help, really I do, but why do I have to be such a bitch? Why can't I just be happy that we're helping? WHY do I feel so reproachful about it? I don't know about myself anymore. I'm not a good person. I lie to people I care about. I do everything wrong. My life always falls to pieces in my hands. I'm such a horrible person. And all I can do is complain. I want to do the world a service by crumpling myself up into a ball and throwing myself away.

The only way to keep your health is to eat what you don't want, drink what you don't like, and do what you'd rather not ~ Mark Twain God, I hate being sick. It makes me feel so pathetic, moaning and whimpering like wounded tiger or something. Despite what you all may be thinking, the only thing thats really wrong with me is my throatits disgustingly swollen (to the point where talking makes me sound like a mentally retarded person with a speech impediment) and covered in open sores, making it almost impossible to eat or drink without feeling like Im trying to swallow a pinecone. For a while I thought it was strep throat, but the cultures came back negative and so I was sent to the Huron Valley hospital for blood tests. The results came back today. The doctors diagnosed me with Infectious Mononucleosis, mono, or the kissing disease for those of us (like me) who are not currently fluent in medical text. They say that I am confined to my house for the next week, and that I am barred from any activity due to the danger of the infection and risk of hospitalization. I hate being locked up. Aside from not being able to swallow without feeling like Im stabbing myself in the back of the throat with a knife, I feel absolutely fine. However, the idea of getting hospitalized kind of scares me. So Ill lock myself in my room for the recommended week, but I wont be happy about it. Because the only thing I knew about mono was that it was spread through the mouth, I decided to do a little research, considering it may or may not be with me for a long, long time. This is what I found out: -Infectious Mononucleosis is an infection caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. This disease effects the lymph tissues and there is an increase of white blood cells that are mononuclear (with a single nucleus). In case you were wondering: Lymph glands are part of the lymphatic system which circulates tissue fluid. The lymphatic system drains fluids from surrounding tissues, filters it, and returns it to the bloodstream. By acting as filters, the lymph glands help to prevent the spread of infection and protect the bloodstream. They can become enlarged with any skin cut or scrape. Most enlarged neck nodes are from minor infections such as colds. -Symptoms of mono include: fever, sore throat (that is a gross understatement), headaches, white patches on the back of your throat, swollen glands in your neck, feeling tired and not feeling hungry. -Mono can be passed not only through saliva but by other less physical contacts, like coughing or sneezing. -Once a person has been infected with mononucleosis, their body may periodically shed (or give off) the virus throughout their lifetime, possibly spreading the virus to others. This can occur despite the fact that they do not have symptoms after their initial mono infection; the virus may still be found in their saliva up to 18 months after they have recovered from their symptoms. -Some newly infected people may not have any symptoms of mono and may not be aware they are spreading the virus that causes mono. -The incubation period for developing mono is 4-8 weeks. -A mono carrier should avoid heavy lifting, contact sports, and vigorous activity for 4-6 weeks after he/she has recovered. This will prevent injury to his/her spleen. -Mono can cause liver inflammation (hepatitis [yowza!]) and spleen enlargement. -Though a mono-diagnosed patient may feel better within 2-4 weeks, recovery can take up to 3 months. -There is no official medical treatment for mono besides plenty of rest. Yeah, you are beautiful, but you don't mean a thing to me..."~ Tiny Vessels by Death Cab for Cutie Think of England It was going to rain. I could tell. The air always tasted different before a storm. The breezes were humming with an electric tension that sent shivers down my spine-- the clouds hovered over the town in a most ominous manner, granite grey and thick with precipitation. Something about the excitement in the atmosphere appealed to me, so I went out for a little outdoor time. I brought a book and an umbrella with me, thinking to do a little reading in the park before the rain set in. I took a breath and sampled the coppery tang to the air. The streets were sparsely occupied, mostly by those bustling to get indoors before they got wet. The storm was still an hour away at the least, but the portentous, eerie buzz in the air sent many people scurrying inside. I made my way down the sidewalk against the flow of the tiny throng, umbrella in one hand and a dog-eared copy of The Catcher in the Rye in the other. I headed for the park, but as the winds picked up their pace and began to whisper of prophetic weather, I thought better of it and selected a street-facing bench to do my reading. I had almost made it through four whole chapters before something caught my eye; across the street, at the top of a five story building, stood a young boy. His silhouette was dark against a canvas of overcast sky as he paced the length of the roof, pausing ever so often to peer tentatively over the ledge at the ground below. I looked around me. No one else had recognized the boy's presence looming over them as dark as the rain clouds. It seemed as if that was the way the boy wanted it-- he kept looking down nervously at the populated sidewalk and shaking his head and wringing his hands. I watched him discreetly from behind Salinger's literature, trying not to draw attention to him by giving him my full interest. His skinny, gangly shadow told him to be young, though it was hard to tell because his facial features were almost impossible to discern from a street away. I could easily make out the tension in his stance and steps-- from where I sat, the boy looked just as ominous as the cloud backdrop behind him. Unceremoniously, he stopped and approached the edge of the roof, clamoring onto the ledge and standing rigidly. He stared down hard at the sidewalk, feet spread apart and hands clenched into tight fists at his sides. The wind blew his shaggy hair around haphazardly, and the electricity in the humid air doubled. I didn't know his name. I didn't know his story. But I knew what he was contemplating. Without a word I ducked my head back into the pages of my book, peeking up at the boy every few paragraphs to see if his position had changed. For a full ten minutes, the boy stood perfectly still. It was as I was finishing Holden's monologue about God and church when a voice cut through the tension between me and the other side of the road. "Look up there!" A small crowd had gathered below where the boy stood, pointed up with open mouths and looking like a flock of turkeys drowning themselves with rain. If the boy's figure was apprehensive before, it was practically paralyzed with trepidation now. "He's gonna jump!" another voice cried out. There was a chorus of 'oh no's and 'sweet Jesus's. It was something that to this day I don't understand. Sweet Jesus was obviously doing nothing for the boy if he was leaning over the roof of a five story building. But no one moved to stop him. They simply watched him and mumbled to themselves how horrible it was, fixated on his stiff body, fascinated by someone so desperate as to throw himself away. It was interestingly morbid, something many had only seen on TV and in movies. And here it was, right up front-- live entertainment. Will he or won't he? Stay tuned for the exciting conclusion of 'Someone Else's Life is Crappier than Yours'. The crowd was too busy gawking at the kid with a sucky life that they forgot to call the police. But they didn't forget to call the news. Basically the same thing... right? Now, don't call my hypocritical. I watched. I'll admit it. I watched and did nothing to stop him. But I also felt I had no right to. Obviously the kid had something going on, and it was enough to drive him to the edge of a fall I had no business in stopping. Not if stopping it meant that the kid would simply go back to what drove him to the fall in the first place. I uncrossed and re-crossed my legs, watching the scene unfold from the safety of my bench across the street. Television cameras and newscasters scrambled out of white vans. Police cars pulled up soon after with their sirens blaring, and a man with a megaphone began yelling at the boy and shouting at the crowd to move back. Probably afraid someone was going to get spattered when the kid dropped. Actually, I was surprised that the boy hadn't gotten it over with by the time they got there-- but it was obvious no one was making a move to get him down. It was too good a scoop; the public was already eating it up. The wind changed as the boy took a nervous step forward. The toe of his ratty tennis shoe hung over the edge of the roof and into the air. The gathering gasped and the reporters narrated, flowering it up as much as possible. From across the street, I could hear their reports: "The boy hesitates-- no, he's taken a stride forward! Oh, cruel world, to throw such a boy into such a horrendous situation! He's dangling on the edge of the rough ledge, hanging a split-second between life and death--" Even from where I sat, I could hear his muffled sobs. His tears would hit the pavement before the rain, I predicted. Speaking of the weather... The clouds had begun to rumble, a guttural growl rolling over the city. The sky had darkened to a deep charcoal color, and the calm breezes that had caressed my face earlier had turned into angry, whipping winds that whistled along the ground. It was going to rain. The people across the street were beginning to jitter nervously, the tension in the air biting at their spines. The boy felt it too-- I could tell. He tilted at a crazy angle, leaning forward with a sharp cry. A woman screamed. With utmost care, I drew myself up off of the bench and collected my things, tucking my book safely under my jacked to protect it from the storm and opening my umbrella. Without looking back, I left as the scent of the air changed again; the boy hit the pavement just as the rain began to fall. The End. -
